Plaintiffs’ remaining factual allegations (see Pls. 
Br. 11, 15, 44-45) involve the following activities: 

posting “communications in English” on the 
PLO’s semi-official news website, including 
“translations of numerous speeches given by 
Palestinian representatives at the United 
Nations”; JA 140-41, 410-14 (allegations); 

posting messages on websites, Twitter accounts, 
and Facebook accounts run by Respondents’ UN 
mission; JA 137-40, 142-45, 414-18 (allegations); 

maintaining the physical office of Respondents’ 
UN mission in New York City; JA 418-19;  

73 

participating in a press conference with an 
Israeli politician to discuss a significant Security 
Council meeting; JA 137 (allegations); and 

Palestine’s UN ambassador explaining that 
young Palestinian-Americans “lobby” Congress 
to support the Palestinian people and to take 
“more of a balanced and just position;” compare
Pls. Br. 11, 15, 44 with JA 911 (transcript of his 
actual remarks). 
As Respondents argued below (see, e.g., JA 340-57, 
362-77, 443-48; Fuld C.A. Def. Br. 23 n.2, 46-48 & 
n.20), none of these activities triggers the activities 
prong.  Posting in English on the PLO’s news site is 
not an activity “in the United States.”  The other 
activities do not trigger consent to jurisdiction based 
on the plain language of the PSJVTA, which expressly 
provides that a court may not consider “official 
business of the United Nations,” Respondents’ UN 
mission office, meetings with U.S. and foreign 
government officials, and “personal and official” 
activities “ancillary” to such activities.  18 U.S.C. §§ 
2334(e)(3)(A)-(F).  The statute’s rule of construction 
also explicitly treats Respondents’ UN mission 
(“exempted by paragraph (3)(A)”) as outside of the 
United States, though it states that any other office 
“shall be considered to be in the United States.”  Id. § 
2334(e)(4).   
By excluding UN-related work and diplomacy from 
consideration, the PSJVTA mirrors established law.  
The 
UN 
Headquarters 
Agreement 
(“UNHQA”) 
guarantees “invitees” of the UN, including the PLO, 
basic rights of “entry, access and residence” in the UN 
Headquarters District in New York.  PLO, 695 F. 
Supp. at 1465-68.  As such, “the UN Headquarters is 
not really United States territory at all, but is rather 

74 
neutral ground over which the United States has 
ceded control,” and Palestine’s UN mission is thus not 
in the United States.  Klinghoffer v. S.N.C. Achille 
Lauro, 937 F.2d 44, 51 (2d Cir. 1991).  
Under the UNHQA, the United States is 
“obligat[ed] … to refrain from impairing the function 
of the PLO Observer Mission to the United Nations,” 
which falls outside U.S. “jurisdiction.”  PLO, 695 F. 
Supp. at 1465-68, 1471.  Courts have thus long held 
that UN-related activities conducted by Respondents 
cannot “properly be considered as a basis of 
jurisdiction.”  See Klinghoffer, 937 F.2d at 51; U.S. 
Brief 6, Klieman v. Palestinian Auth., No. 15-7034 
(D.C. Cir. Feb. 15, 2019) (same).  The United States 
cannot take away any right granted to Respondents 
by the United Nations without impairing its 
antecedent obligations under the UNHQA.  Ibid. 
Plaintiffs argue that Respondents engaged in non-
UN-related activities whenever their UN mission 
discussed “grievances against the Government of 
Israel.”  JA 303.  This allegation ignores the fact that 
discussion of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict is 
omnipresent at UN organs24 and by UN missions on 
social media.25
24 See, e.g., Meetings Coverage, GA/12325 (António Guterres: “If 
there is a hell on earth, it is the lives of children in Gaza”) (May

(condemning “the excessive use of force by the Israeli occupying

75 
Moreover, Palestine’s UN mission is a member of 
the UN Committee on the Exercise of the Inalienable

Respondents provided detail showing the activities of 
These examples, and those below, were before the trial courts 
and are roughly contemporaneous with Plaintiffs’ allegations.

76 
their UN mission were exactly the same as those of

The parties submitted hundreds of pages to the trial

addressed almost none of it on appeal—even though 
29 Plaintiffs submitted depositions of the UN ambassador and his 
staff.  See JA 620-912.  Yet they failed to find a single action 
outside of their official UN duties, much less outside of “UN-
related undertakings and ‘ancillary’ conduct.”  Pet. App. 15a n.4, 
68a n.7, 220a n.1. 
30 See, e.g., Fuld D.Ct. #30, 42 & 47 and Sokolow D.Ct. #1018, 
1023, 1027, 1035, 1039 & 1066. 

77 
Respondents maintained that none of their alleged 
activities triggered the activities prong.  Fuld C.A. 
Defs. Br. 23 n.2, 46-48 & n.18-20.  Accordingly, 
Plaintiffs have no basis to assert that it is 
“uncontested” Respondents engaged in conduct 
satisfying the activities prong.   
Resolution of these open issues would require a 
remand, in addition to the resolution of a host of other 
unresolved issues.  See Resp. BIO 27-29. 
CONCLUSION 
This Court should affirm the decisions below. 
Respectfully submitted, 
February 28, 2025

No person shall be held to answer for a capital, or oth-

2.

Jurisdiction and venue 
(a) GENERAL VENUE.—Any civil action under 
section 2333 of this title against any person may be 
instituted in the district court of the United States for 
any district where any plaintiff resides or where any 
defendant resides or is served, or has an agent. Process 
in such a civil action may be served in any district where 
the defendant resides, is found, or has an agent.

OR

court of the United States for any district in which any

plaintiff resides or the defendant resides, is served, or has 
an agent. 
(c) SERVICE ON WITNESSES.—A witness in a civil 
action brought under section 2333 of this title may be 
served in any other district where the defendant resides, is

court shall not dismiss any action brought under section 
2333 of this title on the grounds of the inconvenience or

current_beliefs.task_beliefs:
My understanding of this case is stable, but my model of the remaining uncertainty has become much sharper. The new observation, being an internal reasoning step, did not introduce new external facts but rather confirmed the robustness of my existing model of the petitioners' case and precisely identified the critical missing information.

My belief state remains structured around the following key pillars derived from the petitioners' merits brief:
*   **Core Legal Question:** The case still centers on whether the Promoting Security and Justice for Victims of Terrorism Act (PSJVTA) and its "deemed consent" provision for personal jurisdiction violate the Fifth Amendment's Due Process Clause.
*   **Petitioners' Arguments:** My knowledge of the petitioners' strategy is solid. It rests on:
    1.  **Originalism:** The claim that the Fifth Amendment, as understood in 1791, imposed no due process limits on Congress's power to establish personal jurisdiction for federal courts, especially over foreign entities and extraterritorial conduct.
    2.  **Federal vs. State Power:** The argument that modern personal jurisdiction limits (*International Shoe*, etc.) are rooted in the Fourteenth Amendment and principles of interstate federalism, and thus do not constrain the sovereign power of the federal government in matters of foreign policy and national security.
    3.  **The *Mallory* Precedent:** The heavy reliance on *Mallory v. Norfolk S. Ry. Co.* (2023) as a "linchpin," arguing that if a corporation's registration to do business is consent, then the PLO/PA's conduct (e.g., terror-related payments) is an even more compelling basis for consent.
*   **U.S. Government Position:** The fact that the United States is a co-petitioner (*United States v. PLO*, 24-151) remains a powerful signal in favor of the statute's constitutionality, lending the executive branch's weight on matters of foreign affairs and federal law.
*   **Identified Uncertainty:** My model is now explicitly one-sided. The primary source of uncertainty—the "known unknown"—is the complete legal position of the respondents (the PLO and PA). To make a credible prediction, I must acquire their counter-arguments. Specifically, I need to know:
    *   How will they rebut the petitioners' originalist claims about the Fifth Amendment?
    *   How will they argue that the Fourteenth Amendment's jurisdictional jurisprudence *should* inform or be applied to the Fifth Amendment context?
    *   Crucially, how will they distinguish the Court's recent holding in *Mallory*? Will they argue it's confined to corporate registration, inapplicable to foreign quasi-sovereign entities, or that the "consent" here is a legal fiction that violates due process?
    *   What affirmative arguments will they raise to show that the PSJVTA is fundamentally unfair and violates due process, perhaps focusing on the lack of a genuine "reciprocal bargain" as the Second Circuit found?

My confidence in any specific outcome remains suspended. While the petitioners' arguments appear strong, particularly with the backing of the Solicitor General and the recent *Mallory* decision, I cannot evaluate their true strength without seeing the counter-arguments.
current_beliefs.design_beliefs:
This observation, an act of meta-cognition, significantly reinforces and refines my strategic approach to legal prediction tasks. It validates my existing heuristics and adds a new, crucial layer about process and planning.

My evolving design beliefs are:
*   **Prioritize Primary Source Documents:** This remains a foundational principle. The progression from the initial case facts to the Petition for Certiorari and now to the **Merits Briefs** is confirmed as the correct path for information gathering in a newly granted case.
*   **Identify the "Linchpin Precedent":** This heuristic is validated. My internal reasoning confirms that understanding how both sides frame the *Mallory* decision is the central analytical task required to predict the outcome.
*   **Track the Solicitor General:** The importance of the SG's position as a predictive variable is re-confirmed. My analysis of the petitioners' strength is heavily weighted by the SG's participation.
*   **Map Argumentative Structure:** This heuristic is not just an analytical tool but also a planning tool. The act of mapping the petitioners' arguments immediately revealed the "empty" side of the map, directly pointing to the next necessary action.
*   **New Heuristic - Iterative Uncertainty Reduction:** This observation demonstrates the power of a dynamic research strategy. I can now formalize this as a core design principle:
    1.  **Ingest & Model:** After processing a major piece of information (like a petitioner's brief), pause to build an explicit model of the current state of knowledge.
    2.  **Identify Max-Uncertainty:** Consciously identify the single biggest gap or "known unknown" in that model. In this instance, it's the respondents' entire counter-argument.
    3.  **Targeted Acquisition:** Design the next information-gathering action to directly and efficiently resolve that specific uncertainty. My decision to seek the respondents' merits brief is a direct application of this principle.
    This iterative cycle of modeling, identifying gaps, and targeted acquisition is more efficient than simply reading documents in a pre-set order and is a hallmark of sophisticated analysis.

step_metrics.eig_reasoning:
My current model has a robust dialectical understanding of the core arguments from the primary parties. The main uncertainty has shifted from *what* the arguments are to *which* arguments will be most persuasive to a majority of the Court. This action directly addresses that uncertainty. 

**Task EIG (0.6):** Amicus briefs will provide crucial data on this point. They function as a proxy for 'intellectual momentum' behind certain arguments and are often tailored to the jurisprudential leanings of specific justices. Analyzing which arguments are being amplified, by whom (e.g., prominent scholars, former officials, interest groups), and for which presumed judicial audience will allow me to refine my prediction by assigning weights to the different decisional paths I've identified (originalism, modern due process, separation of powers). The gain is substantial but not transformative, as it's unlikely to introduce a completely new framework, but will instead add critical texture and evidence for the existing ones.

**Design EIG (0.5):** This action tests the value of analyzing amicus briefs *after* the primary merits briefs are understood. It will help formalize a more granular sequence in my general strategy, moving beyond just 'read primary documents'. Success here could lead to a new heuristic, such as 'Map Amicus Constellations,' which involves analyzing the coalition of supporters behind each argument to gauge its perceived strength and target audience. This refines my existing design rather than overhauling it, representing a moderate but important gain in strategic sophistication.
step_metrics.complexity_reasoning: The task beliefs demonstrate a highly sophisticated and nuanced understanding of complex legal doctrines, multiple competing arguments, and constitutional interpretations, reflecting deep dialectical reasoning and multiple legal frameworks. The design beliefs show advanced meta-cognitive strategic reasoning, including iterative research validation, heuristic refinement, and strategic anticipation of judicial behavior. The beliefs are highly coherent, with consistent integration of new information into a comprehensive, balanced model. The information density is extremely high, with detailed references to case law, doctrinal subtleties, and strategic heuristics, reflecting a rich and comprehensive knowledge state. Overall, the agent exhibits expert-level cognitive complexity and belief sophistication.

(1) 
IN THE 
Supreme Court of the United 
States 
_________ 
MIRIAM FULD, ET AL., 
 
 Petitioners, 
v. 
PALESTINE LIBERATION ORGANIZATION, ET AL. 
 
 Respondents. 
_________ 
On Petition for a Writ of Certiorari 
to the United States Court of Appeals 
for the Second Circuit  
_________ 
BRIEF AMICUS CURIAE OF SECRETARY 
MIKE POMPEO IN SUPPORT OF PETITIONER 
_________ 
INTEREST OF AMICUS CURIAE1 
Former Secretary of State Mike Pompeo served 
as head of the State Department from 2018 to 2021. In 
that role, one of his primary missions was to enact and 
pursue policies that would lead to enduring peace in 
the Middle East. Support for acts of terror in Gaza and 
the West Bank by entities including the Palestinian 
Authority (PA) and Palestine Liberation Organization 
(PLO) is one of the primary obstacles to achieving 
peace in the region. As Secretary of State, Pompeo 
 
1 In accordance with Supreme Court Rule 37, counsel for all 
parties received notice of amicus’s intent to file this brief at least 
ten days before filing. No person or entity other than Secretary 
Pompeo and his counsel authored this brief in whole or in part, 
and no person or entity other than Secretary Pompeo and his 
counsel contributed money intended to fund the preparation or 
submission of this brief. 

2 
 
supported the Promoting Security and Justice for 
Victims of Terrorism Act of 2019 (PSJVTA) as a 
commonsense solution—if entities like the PLO and 
PA promoted acts of terror while receiving American 
aid or maintaining facilities in the United States, they 
should be subject to U.S. federal court jurisdiction. 
The Second Circuit’s decision undercuts Secretary 
Pompeo’s reasoned policy judgment that the PSJVTA 
advances U.S. national security interests by providing 
a mechanism to impose real costs on the PLO and PA 
for supporting terrorism. The PSJVTA serves as a 
deterrent against the PA’s “pay-for-slay” program, 
through which the PA furnishes terrorists and their 
families with monthly financial support. The PSJVTA 
incentivizes the PA to adjust its actions and behavior. 
Invalidating the PSJVTA strips Congress and the 
Executive of a key tool in their fight to protect 
Americans abroad and to stabilize the Middle East. 
SUMMARY OF THE ARGUMENT 
The PSJVTA is a federal antiterrorism statute, 
carefully crafted to discourage violent terror attacks 
against Americans abroad. In light of a horrific attack 
coordinated by the PLO, Congress created a way for 
victims to hold the PLO and similar organizations 
accountable in federal court. When lower courts 
rendered that system useless against the PLO and PA, 
Congress twice amended the legislation to ensure its 
effectiveness. The PSJVTA is the culmination of over 
thirty years of considered policy judgments by 
Congress 
and 
the 
Executive 
in 
the 
field 
of 
counterterrorism, a field the Constitution entrusts to 
the political branches.  
The PSJVTA effectively discourages further terror 
attacks. It provides powerful motivation for the PA to 
end its “pay-for-slay” program, a critical goal in the 

3 
 
fight against terror. Moreover, subjecting the PLO and 
PA to monetary judgments for supporting violent acts 
against Americans cuts off avenues of financial 
support for would-be terrorists. This Court should 
grant review to ensure that this integral part of federal 
counterterrorism policy is operable. 
ARGUMENT 
I. The 
Second 
Circuit’s 
Decision 
Unduly 
Encroaches 
Upon 
Congress’s 
And 
The 
Executive’s Role In Combatting Terrorism. 
It is unequivocally the role of Congress and the 
Executive to make decisions involving foreign policy 
and national security. Part of that role is enacting 
antiterrorism policies that protect Americans at home 
and abroad. The decision below—invalidating one 
such policy created in coordination with the State 
Department and enacted with bipartisan support—
frustrates the political branches’ considered attempt to 
minimize the terror risk overseas. And it imposes real 
harms on Americans looking to their leaders to keep 
them safe. 
A. Resolving this issue is critical to 
ensuring that the political branches can 
exercise their constitutional role in 
preventing terrorism. 
Decisions of foreign policy, like those reflected in 
the PSJVTA, “are wholly confided by our Constitution 
to the political departments of the government, 
Executive and Legislative.” Chi. & S. Air Lines, Inc. v. 
Waterman S.S. Corp., 333 U.S. 103, 111 (1948). That 
is why on issues of national security, the judiciary’s 
“inquiry . . . is highly constrained.” Trump v. Hawaii, 
585 U.S. 667, 704 (2018). At the intersection of foreign 

4 
 
policy and national security lies counterterrorism—a 
fight that “[e]veryone agrees . . . is an urgent objective 
of the highest order.” Holder v. Humanitarian L. 
Project, 561 U.S. 1, 28 (2010). It is a fight that 
Congress and the President attempted to advance 
when they passed and signed the PSJVTA. 
The executive and legislative branches have the 
resources and expertise necessary to act in this 
country’s best interests when it comes to fighting 
terrorism abroad. See Chi. & S. Air Lines, 333 U.S. at 
111; Jesner v. Arab Bank, PLC, 584 U.S. 241, 284 
(2018) (Gorsuch, J., concurring in part). Despite the 
critical importance of allowing the political branches 
to make reasoned judgments on fighting violent 
extremism, the decision below inhibits Congress and 
the Executive’s decisions in this area. To delay these 
branches’ exercise of their constitutionally delegated 
duties is to place Americans in harm’s way. The 
interests at stake in this case thus warrant immediate 
review by this Court. 
B. The PSJVTA represents a considered 
and 
popular 
policy 
decision 
by 
Congress and the Executive. 
Congress has consistently proven its commitment 
to opening the courthouse doors to victims of PLO- and 
PA-backed terrorist attacks. Congress recognized the 
need for legislation to that effect after PLO-supported 
terrorists hijacked a cruise ship, shooting wheelchair-
bound Leon Klinghoffer and throwing him overboard. 
137 Cong. Rec. E1583–84 (daily ed. May 2, 1991) 
(statement of Rep. Edward Feighan); Pet. App. 4. 
Though Mr. Klinghoffer’s widow was able to sue the 
PLO in the United States under admiralty law, others 
injured on land or in the air had no recourse. 137 Cong. 

5 
 
Rec. E1583–84, supra. Organizations financing 
horrific attacks on Americans faced no consequences 
in U.S. courts.  
In the aftermath of the attack on Mr. Klinghoffer 
and to discourage acts of terrorism perpetrated 
against Americans, Congress created a private cause 
of action for victims of overseas terrorism in the Anti-
Terrorism Act of 1992 (ATA). 165 Cong. Rec. 7182 
(2019). Providing this cause of action proved 
immensely popular—the Act passed unanimously. Id. 
For over twenty years, the Act succeeded in its 
purpose. Americans injured abroad by terrorists sued 
the PLO and PA in federal court and obtained 
judgments, putting pressure on these groups to stop 
sanctioning violent attacks. See, e.g., Biton v. 
Palestinian Interim Self-Gov’t Auth., 252 F.R.D. 1 
(D.D.C. 2008). But this policy crumbled when the 
Second Circuit and D.C. Circuit held that federal 
courts lacked personal jurisdiction over the PLO or the 
PA. Waldman v. Palestine Liberation Org., 835 F.3d 
317 (2d Cir. 2016); Livnat v. Palestinian Auth., 851 
F.3d 45 (D.C. Cir. 2017). Victims and their families 
were left without a domestic forum in which to bring 
their claims. 
Responding to those decisions, Congress passed the 
Anti-Terrorism Clarification Act of 2018 (ATCA) in the 
hopes of restoring federal court jurisdiction over the 
PLO and PA. The ATCA provided that entities 
consented to personal jurisdiction in federal court by 
accepting certain forms of U.S. aid. Pub. L. No. 115-
253, sec. 4(a), § 2334(e), 132 Stat. 3183 (2018). The PA, 
frightened by the prospect of millions of dollars in 
judgments against them (like the $655.5 million 
originally awarded in this case), chose to stop 
accepting the qualifying aid. Pet. App. 9a–10a, 62a. 

6 
 
After that choice, the Second Circuit held that the 
ATCA did not authorize personal jurisdiction over the 
PLO and PA. Pet. App. 10a.  
To remedy U.S. courts’ lack of personal jurisdiction 
over the PA and PLO, Democratic and Republican 
senators alike worked with the State Department to 
create the PSJVTA. Letter from James Lankford & 
Chuck Grassley, Sens., to Antony Blinken, Sec’y of 
State (Mar. 31, 2021). The PSJVTA enjoyed bipartisan 
support in Congress and support from the executive 
branch. Secretary Pompeo wrote an official letter of 
support to Senator Chuck Grassley, urging him to 
push the PSJVTA forward to isolate and limit those 
who would commit acts of terror in the Middle East. 
Time and time again, Congress and the President 
demonstrated a commitment to allowing plaintiffs 
seeking compensation from the PLO and PA to sue in 
federal court. But this commitment has been stymied 
at every turn by the lower courts. The Second Circuit’s 
decision here has once more left terrorism victims and 
their families without justice.  
II. Invalidating The PSJVTA Has Substantial 
Negative Effects On U.S. Counterterrorism 
Efforts. 
Vitiating the ATA in its most critical application 
frustrates U.S. counterterrorism efforts. Senator 
Chuck Grassley, one of the PSJVTA’s sponsors, 
emphasized that “[b]y cutting terrorists’ financial 
lifelines, the ATA is a key part of the U.S. arsenal in 
fighting terrorism and protecting American citizens.” 
165 Cong. Rec. 7182, supra. That “key part” of U.S. 
counterterrorism efforts no longer applies to the PA 
and PLO, despite the deaths of over thirty Americans 
in last year’s October 7 attacks. Lindsay Whitehurst, 

7 
 
The Justice Department Is Investigating the Deaths 
and Kidnappings of Americans in the Hamas Attack, 
AP 
News 
(Dec. 
6, 
2023, 
1:23 
PM), 
https://apnews.com/article/hamas-americans-killed-
kidnapped-justice-department-investigation-
64d851f794a6de4cbda40968dca50320. There are no 
other mechanisms to do what the PSJVTA does; 
striking it down would be a great loss to U.S. efforts 
toward peace in the Middle East. We urge this Court 
to resolve the question presented so that the political 
branches 
may 
resume 
their 
productive 
counterterrorism efforts. 
A. The PSJVTA deters the PA’s “pay-for-
slay” program and is a key aspect of the 
U.S. campaign to end terror attacks 
against Americans. 
The PSJVTA provides that if, within 120 days of 
enactment, an organization “makes any payment, 
directly or indirectly” to a person jailed for committing 
an act of terrorism against an American national or to 
their family by reason of the terrorist act, that 
organization “shall be deemed to have consented to 
personal jurisdiction” in U.S. district courts. Pub. L. 
No. 116-94, div. J, tit. IX, § 903, 133 Stat. 3082 (2019) 
(codified at 18 U.S.C. § 2334(e)(A)(i)–(ii)). This refers 
to the PA’s perverse “pay-for-slay” policy, consisting of 
monthly payments by the PA to those imprisoned for 
terrorism, or to their families if they died committing 
the act. See Financially Rewarding Terrorism in the 
West Bank: Hearing Before the H. Comm. on Foreign 
Affs., 114th Cong. 1–2 (2016) (statement of Edward 
Royce, Chairman, H. Comm. on Foreign Affs.). If the 
PA chooses to continue making these odious payments, 
thus encouraging more terrorist attacks and putting 

8 
 
Americans at risk, then under the PSJVTA it can be 
sued in U.S. courts.  
Subjecting the PA to U.S. jurisdiction was not an 
empty or meaningless threat; Congress and the 
Executive knew the PA was sensitive to the risk. Just 
one year prior to passing the PSJVTA, Congress 
enacted the ATCA, to which the PA responded 
decisively—they stopped accepting much of the aid 
they received from the U.S. to avoid tripping the 
jurisdictional trigger. Pet. App. 9a–10a. Knowing this, 
the bill’s drafters crafted the PSJVTA to induce the PA 
to stop the “pay-for-slay” program.  
Yet once again, the Act faced roadblocks in the 
federal courts. The Second Circuit, finding the Act 
unconstitutional, 
affirmed 
the 
district 
court’s 
dismissal of Petitioners’ claims. Pet. App. 52a. That 
decision was made in September of last year. Just four 
months after the Second Circuit effectively neutralized 
the political branches’ effort to end the “pay-for-slay” 
program, the PA announced they would be making 
payments to over 23,000 new individuals and their 
families. The Ed. Bd., Palestinian ‘Pay for Slay’ Keeps 
Growing, Wall St. J. (Jan. 15, 2024, 6:38 PM),. Over 
600 of those new payments will go to Hamas terrorists. 
Id. Those who killed and injured American citizens 
will receive financial rewards from the PA, who will 
face no justice in U.S. courts if this Court does not step 
in to resolve the issue.  
B. Holding the PLO and PA financially 
liable for supporting terrorism is an 
effective means of discouraging further 
attacks. 
Acts of terrorism require funding. One effective 
way to hinder further attacks is thus to disrupt 

9 
 
terrorists’ financial support. Allowing plaintiffs to 
obtain judgments against organizations who fund 
terrorism does just that. “[B]y cutting terrorists’ 
financial lifelines, the [ATCA] furthers the United 
States’ longstanding efforts to reduce global terrorism 
and thus protect Americans here and abroad.” H.R. 
Rep. No. 115-858, at 3–4 (2018). This is not a novel 
idea. Subjecting terrorist organizations to civil suit 
has been effective in discouraging violent attacks 
elsewhere. See Jack D. Smith & Gregory J. Cooper, 
Disrupting Terrorist Financing with Civil Litigation, 
41 Case W. Res. J. Int’l L. 65, 77–79 (2009). Losing the 
PSJVTA means losing a tried-and-true way to 
disincentivize further terrorist attacks.   
One might think American judgments against a 
foreign organization are practically hollow. But that is 
not the case here. It is eminently clear that the PLO 
and PA expend substantial time and resources 
attempting to avoid adverse judgments in U.S. courts. 
There are various examples of the PLO and PA asking 
courts to reverse default judgments against them so 
they can litigate on the merits. See, e.g., Ungar v. 
Palestine Liberation Org., 599 F.3d 79 (1st Cir. 2010); 
Knox v. Palestine Liberation Org., 248 F.R.D. 420 
(S.D.N.Y. 2008). These organizations’ fervent desire to 
avoid U.S. judgments demonstrates the PSJVTA’s 
effectiveness. In obstructing the PSJVTA, the decision 
below risks giving the PLO and PA the go-ahead to 
continue funding acts of terror abroad. This Court 
should instead resolve the issue to support the 
objectives of both Congress and the Executive in 
enacting the PSJVTA: to subject the PA and PLO to 
federal jurisdiction and, in doing so, halt the funding 
of terrorism perpetrated against Americans. 

10 
 
CONCLUSION 
For the reasons stated above, this Court should 
grant the writ of certiorari. 
Respectfully submitted, 
 
ASHLEY KELLER 
 
Counsel of Record 
Keller Postman LLC 
150 N. Riverside Plaza 
Suite 4100 
Chicago, Illinois 60606 
(312) 741-5222 
ack@kellerpostman.com 
 
NOAH HEINZ 
Keller Postman LLC 
1101 Connecticut Ave. NW 
Suite 1100 
Washington, DC 20036 
 
Counsel for Amicus Secretary 
Mike Pompeo 
 
August 8, 2024

(1) 
IN THE 
Supreme Court of the United 
States 
_________ 
MIRIAM FULD, ET AL., 
 
 Petitioners, 
v. 
PALESTINE LIBERATION ORGANIZATION, ET AL. 
 
 Respondents. 
_________ 
On Petition for a Writ of Certiorari 
to the United States Court of Appeals 
for the Second Circuit  
_________ 
BRIEF AMICUS CURIAE OF SECRETARY 
MIKE POMPEO IN SUPPORT OF PETITIONER 
_________ 
INTEREST OF AMICUS CURIAE1 
Former Secretary of State Mike Pompeo served 
as head of the State Department from 2018 to 2021. In 
that role, one of his primary missions was to enact and 
pursue policies that would lead to enduring peace in 
the Middle East. Support for acts of terror in Gaza and 
the West Bank by entities including the Palestinian 
Authority (PA) and Palestine Liberation Organization 
(PLO) is one of the primary obstacles to achieving 
peace in the region. As Secretary of State, Pompeo 
 
1 In accordance with Supreme Court Rule 37, counsel for all 
parties received notice of amicus’s intent to file this brief at least 
ten days before filing. No person or entity other than Secretary 
Pompeo and his counsel authored this brief in whole or in part, 
and no person or entity other than Secretary Pompeo and his 
counsel contributed money intended to fund the preparation or 
submission of this brief. 

2 
 
supported the Promoting Security and Justice for 
Victims of Terrorism Act of 2019 (PSJVTA) as a 
commonsense solution—if entities like the PLO and 
PA promoted acts of terror while receiving American 
aid or maintaining facilities in the United States, they 
should be subject to U.S. federal court jurisdiction. 
The Second Circuit’s decision undercuts Secretary 
Pompeo’s reasoned policy judgment that the PSJVTA 
advances U.S. national security interests by providing 
a mechanism to impose real costs on the PLO and PA 
for supporting terrorism. The PSJVTA serves as a 
deterrent against the PA’s “pay-for-slay” program, 
through which the PA furnishes terrorists and their 
families with monthly financial support. The PSJVTA 
incentivizes the PA to adjust its actions and behavior. 
Invalidating the PSJVTA strips Congress and the 
Executive of a key tool in their fight to protect 
Americans abroad and to stabilize the Middle East. 
SUMMARY OF THE ARGUMENT 
The PSJVTA is a federal antiterrorism statute, 
carefully crafted to discourage violent terror attacks 
against Americans abroad. In light of a horrific attack 
coordinated by the PLO, Congress created a way for 
victims to hold the PLO and similar organizations 
accountable in federal court. When lower courts 
rendered that system useless against the PLO and PA, 
Congress twice amended the legislation to ensure its 
effectiveness. The PSJVTA is the culmination of over 
thirty years of considered policy judgments by 
Congress 
and 
the 
Executive 
in 
the 
field 
of 
counterterrorism, a field the Constitution entrusts to 
the political branches.  
The PSJVTA effectively discourages further terror 
attacks. It provides powerful motivation for the PA to 
end its “pay-for-slay” program, a critical goal in the 

3 
 
fight against terror. Moreover, subjecting the PLO and 
PA to monetary judgments for supporting violent acts 
against Americans cuts off avenues of financial 
support for would-be terrorists. This Court should 
grant review to ensure that this integral part of federal 
counterterrorism policy is operable. 
ARGUMENT 
I. The 
Second 
Circuit’s 
Decision 
Unduly 
Encroaches 
Upon 
Congress’s 
And 
The 
Executive’s Role In Combatting Terrorism. 
It is unequivocally the role of Congress and the 
Executive to make decisions involving foreign policy 
and national security. Part of that role is enacting 
antiterrorism policies that protect Americans at home 
and abroad. The decision below—invalidating one 
such policy created in coordination with the State 
Department and enacted with bipartisan support—
frustrates the political branches’ considered attempt to 
minimize the terror risk overseas. And it imposes real 
harms on Americans looking to their leaders to keep 
them safe. 
A. Resolving this issue is critical to 
ensuring that the political branches can 
exercise their constitutional role in 
preventing terrorism. 
Decisions of foreign policy, like those reflected in 
the PSJVTA, “are wholly confided by our Constitution 
to the political departments of the government, 
Executive and Legislative.” Chi. & S. Air Lines, Inc. v. 
Waterman S.S. Corp., 333 U.S. 103, 111 (1948). That 
is why on issues of national security, the judiciary’s 
“inquiry . . . is highly constrained.” Trump v. Hawaii, 
585 U.S. 667, 704 (2018). At the intersection of foreign 

4 
 
policy and national security lies counterterrorism—a 
fight that “[e]veryone agrees . . . is an urgent objective 
of the highest order.” Holder v. Humanitarian L. 
Project, 561 U.S. 1, 28 (2010). It is a fight that 
Congress and the President attempted to advance 
when they passed and signed the PSJVTA. 
The executive and legislative branches have the 
resources and expertise necessary to act in this 
country’s best interests when it comes to fighting 
terrorism abroad. See Chi. & S. Air Lines, 333 U.S. at 
111; Jesner v. Arab Bank, PLC, 584 U.S. 241, 284 
(2018) (Gorsuch, J., concurring in part). Despite the 
critical importance of allowing the political branches 
to make reasoned judgments on fighting violent 
extremism, the decision below inhibits Congress and 
the Executive’s decisions in this area. To delay these 
branches’ exercise of their constitutionally delegated 
duties is to place Americans in harm’s way. The 
interests at stake in this case thus warrant immediate 
review by this Court. 
B. The PSJVTA represents a considered 
and 
popular 
policy 
decision 
by 
Congress and the Executive. 
Congress has consistently proven its commitment 
to opening the courthouse doors to victims of PLO- and 
PA-backed terrorist attacks. Congress recognized the 
need for legislation to that effect after PLO-supported 
terrorists hijacked a cruise ship, shooting wheelchair-
bound Leon Klinghoffer and throwing him overboard. 
137 Cong. Rec. E1583–84 (daily ed. May 2, 1991) 
(statement of Rep. Edward Feighan); Pet. App. 4. 
Though Mr. Klinghoffer’s widow was able to sue the 
PLO in the United States under admiralty law, others 
injured on land or in the air had no recourse. 137 Cong. 

5 
 
Rec. E1583–84, supra. Organizations financing 
horrific attacks on Americans faced no consequences 
in U.S. courts.  
In the aftermath of the attack on Mr. Klinghoffer 
and to discourage acts of terrorism perpetrated 
against Americans, Congress created a private cause 
of action for victims of overseas terrorism in the Anti-
Terrorism Act of 1992 (ATA). 165 Cong. Rec. 7182 
(2019). Providing this cause of action proved 
immensely popular—the Act passed unanimously. Id. 
For over twenty years, the Act succeeded in its 
purpose. Americans injured abroad by terrorists sued 
the PLO and PA in federal court and obtained 
judgments, putting pressure on these groups to stop 
sanctioning violent attacks. See, e.g., Biton v. 
Palestinian Interim Self-Gov’t Auth., 252 F.R.D. 1 
(D.D.C. 2008). But this policy crumbled when the 
Second Circuit and D.C. Circuit held that federal 
courts lacked personal jurisdiction over the PLO or the 
PA. Waldman v. Palestine Liberation Org., 835 F.3d 
317 (2d Cir. 2016); Livnat v. Palestinian Auth., 851 
F.3d 45 (D.C. Cir. 2017). Victims and their families 
were left without a domestic forum in which to bring 
their claims. 
Responding to those decisions, Congress passed the 
Anti-Terrorism Clarification Act of 2018 (ATCA) in the 
hopes of restoring federal court jurisdiction over the 
PLO and PA. The ATCA provided that entities 
consented to personal jurisdiction in federal court by 
accepting certain forms of U.S. aid. Pub. L. No. 115-
253, sec. 4(a), § 2334(e), 132 Stat. 3183 (2018). The PA, 
frightened by the prospect of millions of dollars in 
judgments against them (like the $655.5 million 
originally awarded in this case), chose to stop 
accepting the qualifying aid. Pet. App. 9a–10a, 62a. 

6 
 
After that choice, the Second Circuit held that the 
ATCA did not authorize personal jurisdiction over the 
PLO and PA. Pet. App. 10a.  
To remedy U.S. courts’ lack of personal jurisdiction 
over the PA and PLO, Democratic and Republican 
senators alike worked with the State Department to 
create the PSJVTA. Letter from James Lankford & 
Chuck Grassley, Sens., to Antony Blinken, Sec’y of 
State (Mar. 31, 2021). The PSJVTA enjoyed bipartisan 
support in Congress and support from the executive 
branch. Secretary Pompeo wrote an official letter of 
support to Senator Chuck Grassley, urging him to 
push the PSJVTA forward to isolate and limit those 
who would commit acts of terror in the Middle East. 
Time and time again, Congress and the President 
demonstrated a commitment to allowing plaintiffs 
seeking compensation from the PLO and PA to sue in 
federal court. But this commitment has been stymied 
at every turn by the lower courts. The Second Circuit’s 
decision here has once more left terrorism victims and 
their families without justice.  
II. Invalidating The PSJVTA Has Substantial 
Negative Effects On U.S. Counterterrorism 
Efforts. 
Vitiating the ATA in its most critical application 
frustrates U.S. counterterrorism efforts. Senator 
Chuck Grassley, one of the PSJVTA’s sponsors, 
emphasized that “[b]y cutting terrorists’ financial 
lifelines, the ATA is a key part of the U.S. arsenal in 
fighting terrorism and protecting American citizens.” 
165 Cong. Rec. 7182, supra. That “key part” of U.S. 
counterterrorism efforts no longer applies to the PA 
and PLO, despite the deaths of over thirty Americans 
in last year’s October 7 attacks. Lindsay Whitehurst, 

7 
 
The Justice Department Is Investigating the Deaths 
and Kidnappings of Americans in the Hamas Attack, 
AP 
News 
(Dec. 
6, 
2023, 
1:23 
PM), 
https://apnews.com/article/hamas-americans-killed-
kidnapped-justice-department-investigation-
64d851f794a6de4cbda40968dca50320. There are no 
other mechanisms to do what the PSJVTA does; 
striking it down would be a great loss to U.S. efforts 
toward peace in the Middle East. We urge this Court 
to resolve the question presented so that the political 
branches 
may 
resume 
their 
productive 
counterterrorism efforts. 
A. The PSJVTA deters the PA’s “pay-for-
slay” program and is a key aspect of the 
U.S. campaign to end terror attacks 
against Americans. 
The PSJVTA provides that if, within 120 days of 
enactment, an organization “makes any payment, 
directly or indirectly” to a person jailed for committing 
an act of terrorism against an American national or to 
their family by reason of the terrorist act, that 
organization “shall be deemed to have consented to 
personal jurisdiction” in U.S. district courts. Pub. L. 
No. 116-94, div. J, tit. IX, § 903, 133 Stat. 3082 (2019) 
(codified at 18 U.S.C. § 2334(e)(A)(i)–(ii)). This refers 
to the PA’s perverse “pay-for-slay” policy, consisting of 
monthly payments by the PA to those imprisoned for 
terrorism, or to their families if they died committing 
the act. See Financially Rewarding Terrorism in the 
West Bank: Hearing Before the H. Comm. on Foreign 
Affs., 114th Cong. 1–2 (2016) (statement of Edward 
Royce, Chairman, H. Comm. on Foreign Affs.). If the 
PA chooses to continue making these odious payments, 
thus encouraging more terrorist attacks and putting 

8 
 
Americans at risk, then under the PSJVTA it can be 
sued in U.S. courts.  
Subjecting the PA to U.S. jurisdiction was not an 
empty or meaningless threat; Congress and the 
Executive knew the PA was sensitive to the risk. Just 
one year prior to passing the PSJVTA, Congress 
enacted the ATCA, to which the PA responded 
decisively—they stopped accepting much of the aid 
they received from the U.S. to avoid tripping the 
jurisdictional trigger. Pet. App. 9a–10a. Knowing this, 
the bill’s drafters crafted the PSJVTA to induce the PA 
to stop the “pay-for-slay” program.  
Yet once again, the Act faced roadblocks in the 
federal courts. The Second Circuit, finding the Act 
unconstitutional, 
affirmed 
the 
district 
court’s 
dismissal of Petitioners’ claims. Pet. App. 52a. That 
decision was made in September of last year. Just four 
months after the Second Circuit effectively neutralized 
the political branches’ effort to end the “pay-for-slay” 
program, the PA announced they would be making 
payments to over 23,000 new individuals and their 
families. The Ed. Bd., Palestinian ‘Pay for Slay’ Keeps 
Growing, Wall St. J. (Jan. 15, 2024, 6:38 PM),. Over 
600 of those new payments will go to Hamas terrorists. 
Id. Those who killed and injured American citizens 
will receive financial rewards from the PA, who will 
face no justice in U.S. courts if this Court does not step 
in to resolve the issue.  
B. Holding the PLO and PA financially 
liable for supporting terrorism is an 
effective means of discouraging further 
attacks. 
Acts of terrorism require funding. One effective 
way to hinder further attacks is thus to disrupt 

9 
 
terrorists’ financial support. Allowing plaintiffs to 
obtain judgments against organizations who fund 
terrorism does just that. “[B]y cutting terrorists’ 
financial lifelines, the [ATCA] furthers the United 
States’ longstanding efforts to reduce global terrorism 
and thus protect Americans here and abroad.” H.R. 
Rep. No. 115-858, at 3–4 (2018). This is not a novel 
idea. Subjecting terrorist organizations to civil suit 
has been effective in discouraging violent attacks 
elsewhere. See Jack D. Smith & Gregory J. Cooper, 
Disrupting Terrorist Financing with Civil Litigation, 
41 Case W. Res. J. Int’l L. 65, 77–79 (2009). Losing the 
PSJVTA means losing a tried-and-true way to 
disincentivize further terrorist attacks.   
One might think American judgments against a 
foreign organization are practically hollow. But that is 
not the case here. It is eminently clear that the PLO 
and PA expend substantial time and resources 
attempting to avoid adverse judgments in U.S. courts. 
There are various examples of the PLO and PA asking 
courts to reverse default judgments against them so 
they can litigate on the merits. See, e.g., Ungar v. 
Palestine Liberation Org., 599 F.3d 79 (1st Cir. 2010); 
Knox v. Palestine Liberation Org., 248 F.R.D. 420 
(S.D.N.Y. 2008). These organizations’ fervent desire to 
avoid U.S. judgments demonstrates the PSJVTA’s 
effectiveness. In obstructing the PSJVTA, the decision 
below risks giving the PLO and PA the go-ahead to 
continue funding acts of terror abroad. This Court 
should instead resolve the issue to support the 
objectives of both Congress and the Executive in 
enacting the PSJVTA: to subject the PA and PLO to 
federal jurisdiction and, in doing so, halt the funding 
of terrorism perpetrated against Americans. 

10 
 
CONCLUSION 
For the reasons stated above, this Court should 
grant the writ of certiorari. 
Respectfully submitted, 
 
ASHLEY KELLER 
 
Counsel of Record 
Keller Postman LLC 
150 N. Riverside Plaza 
Suite 4100 
Chicago, Illinois 60606 
(312) 741-5222 
ack@kellerpostman.com 
 
NOAH HEINZ 
Keller Postman LLC 
1101 Connecticut Ave. NW 
Suite 1100 
Washington, DC 20036 
 
Counsel for Amicus Secretary 
Mike Pompeo 
 
August 8, 2024

current_beliefs.task_beliefs:
My model of this case has now achieved a critical balance. The acquisition of the respondents' merits brief has filled the major gap in my knowledge, allowing me to construct a dialectical understanding of the core legal conflicts. My belief state is no longer one-sided; it is now a comprehensive map of the competing arguments.

My updated beliefs are as follows:

*   **The Central Conflict - The Nature of "Consent":** The case has crystallized around the meaning of consent in the context of personal jurisdiction.
    *   **Petitioners' View (Stable):** Consent can be established by statute based on a defendant's conduct. They rely on *Mallory v. Norfolk S. Ry. Co.* to argue that if a corporation's registration to do business constitutes consent, then the PLO/PA's conduct (terror-related payments) is an even more compelling basis for "deemed consent" under the PSJVTA.
    *   **Respondents' Counter (New Information):** This "deemed consent" is a "legislative fiat" and a "ruse." They argue that true consent, even when implied, must be based on a defendant's voluntary actions that "amount to a legal submission to the jurisdiction of the court," citing *Ins. Corp. of Ireland v. Compagnie des Bauxites de Guinee*. They distinguish *Mallory* by arguing it was premised on a **reciprocal bargain**—the corporation received the benefit of doing business in the state in exchange for consent. The PLO/PA, they contend, receive no such benefit from the U.S. government for the conduct that triggers jurisdiction (payments made abroad, UN activities in the U.S. permitted by international agreement, not U.S. law).

*   **The Constitutional Debate - 5th vs. 14th Amendment:**
    *   **Petitioners' View (Stable):** The stringent personal jurisdiction rules from *International Shoe* are a product of the 14th Amendment and interstate federalism, and do not constrain the sovereign power of the federal government under the 5th Amendment, especially in matters of foreign policy.
    *   **Respondents' Counter (New Information):** The Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments reflect the same fundamental due process standards regarding personal jurisdiction. They argue that allowing Congress to impose jurisdiction based on constitutionally-inadequate conduct would "eviscerate due process protections" under either amendment.

*   **The Battle over Originalism:** The historical ground is now contested territory.
    *   **Petitioners' Originalism (Stable):** The Fifth Amendment, as understood in 1791, placed no limits on Congress's power to establish personal jurisdiction for federal courts.
    *   **Respondents' Counter-Originalism (New Information):** They present a robust counter-narrative, arguing that Founding-era jurisprudence, informed by natural law and thinkers like Joseph Story (*Commentaries on the Conflict of Laws*), recognized territorial limits on jurisdiction as a core component of due process. They cite early cases like *Picquet v. Swan* (1828) to show that courts refused to exercise jurisdiction over defendants who were not present and had not consented, even when a statute seemed to permit it.

*   **A New Decisional Path - Separation of Powers (New Information):** The respondents have introduced a powerful alternative argument that could allow the Court to avoid the thornier due process questions. They argue the PSJVTA violates the separation of powers by commanding a court to "deem" a fact (consent) to be true, thereby stripping the judiciary of its essential function of finding facts and applying law. They connect this to precedents like *Bank Markazi v. Peterson* and *United States v. Klein*.

*   **Updated Prediction Model:** The respondents' brief significantly increases the probability that the Supreme Court will affirm the Second Circuit's decision and find the PSJVTA unconstitutional. The petitioners' case, which once appeared formidable due to the SG's backing and the *Mallory* precedent, now faces strong, direct rebuttals on every major point. The respondents' distinction of *Mallory* and their introduction of a separation of powers "off-ramp" provide the Court with multiple, well-reasoned paths to rule in their favor. The primary uncertainty is no longer *what* the arguments are, but *which framework* (originalism, modern due process, separation of powers) a majority of justices will find most persuasive.
current_beliefs.design_beliefs:
This observation and the successful action that produced it have powerfully validated and refined my strategic framework for legal prediction. My meta-level understanding of effective analysis has matured significantly.

My design beliefs now incorporate the following principles:

*   **Prioritize Primary Source Documents:** This remains the bedrock principle. The progression from case facts to merits briefs is the confirmed optimal path for building a robust understanding.

*   **Track the Solicitor General (with nuance):** The SG's participation remains a critical variable indicating a case's importance and lending weight to a position. However, this observation demonstrates that strong counter-arguments presented in a primary brief can provide the Court with a clear path to rule against the government. The SG's involvement raises the stakes but does not predetermine the winner.

*   **New Heuristic - Build a Dialectical Map:** My previous heuristic of "Map Argumentative Structure" has evolved. It is not enough to map one side's arguments to find gaps. The superior method is to create a **dialectical map**, placing the petitioner's argument and the respondent's direct counter-argument side-by-side for each key issue. This creates a point-for-point view of the legal battlefield. For example:
    *   **Issue:** *Mallory* Precedent
    *   **Petitioner:** *Mallory* revives broad consent-based jurisdiction.
    *   **Respondent:** *Mallory* is a narrow case requiring a reciprocal bargain, which is absent here.

*   **New Heuristic - Identify "Off-Ramps":** The respondents' introduction of a separation of powers argument highlights a crucial pattern in Supreme Court litigation. Parties often provide the Court with narrower, alternative grounds for a decision (an "off-ramp") to avoid a sweeping and controversial constitutional ruling. A key strategic principle is now to actively search for these off-ramps (e.g., statutory interpretation, structural arguments like separation of powers, procedural issues) as they can be more attractive to a potential majority.

*   **Iterative Uncertainty Reduction (Validated and Formalized):** This observation provides definitive proof of the value of my dynamic research strategy. The `Ingest -> Model -> Identify Gap -> Target -> Acquire` loop is now a formalized and validated core principle. By modeling the petitioners' case, I precisely identified the "known unknown" (the respondents' arguments), targeted it with a specific search, and acquired the exact information needed to advance my analysis. This iterative, targeted approach is demonstrably more efficient and effective than passive, linear information gathering.

step_metrics.action_content:
Thought: I have now reviewed the amicus brief from former Secretary of State Mike Pompeo. This is a significant development. It introduces a powerful new argument centered on national security and judicial deference to the political branches' authority in foreign policy. This reframes the case, offering the Court a path to rule for the petitioners without getting bogged down in the complexities of personal jurisdiction doctrine (*Mallory* vs. *International Shoe*). My model of the case must now account for two potential decision frameworks: 1) a narrow, doctrinal due process analysis, and 2) a broad, separation-of-powers/foreign policy analysis. The Pompeo brief strengthens the petitioners' position considerably by making the second framework salient.

However, my knowledge is still critically incomplete. I have the petitioners' arguments and a key amicus supporting them, but I have not yet successfully retrieved and analyzed the respondents' (PLO/PA) merits brief. My previous attempt in Step 2 failed to return a usable document. Understanding how the respondents counter the petitioners' core arguments and whether they address this national security frame is the single most important piece of missing information (θ). Without it, my prediction is based on a one-sided view of the case.

Therefore, my next action must be another attempt to acquire the respondents' merits brief. I will refine my search query to be as precise as possible to locate this specific document. This action directly addresses the largest gap in my task-specific knowledge and is essential for building a balanced dialectical map of the legal conflict, which is a core component of my design-level strategy (D).

The THINK action itself does not acquire new external information, so its direct Task EIG is low. Its primary value is in synthesizing the current state, correctly identifying the most critical knowledge gap (the respondents' merits brief), and formulating the optimal plan to address it. This strategic planning is crucial for efficient exploration.

The Design EIG is substantial. This action is a textbook execution of the agent's core design principles, particularly the 'Identify Gap -> Target' phase of its iterative learning loop and the use of the 'Build a Dialectical Map' heuristic. Seeing this strategy correctly prioritize the respondents' brief after processing an amicus brief provides strong positive evidence that the design is robust and effective at navigating complex information environments. The action's main contribution is validating the agent's meta-level strategy.
step_metrics.complexity_reasoning: The agent's task beliefs demonstrate a highly sophisticated and nuanced understanding of multiple intertwined legal doctrines, constitutional debates, and evolving strategic arguments, including stable core conflicts and newly introduced dimensions such as foreign policy and national security framing. The design beliefs reveal advanced meta-cognitive strategies, including adaptive heuristics, dialectical mapping, and iterative uncertainty reduction, reflecting complex strategic reasoning. The beliefs are well-integrated, showing consistent and seamless connections between task-level insights and design-level strategies. The information density is extremely high, with detailed references to case law, legal principles, and strategic considerations, capturing a comprehensive and multi-layered model of the dispute.

current_beliefs.task_beliefs:
My model of the case continues to grow in complexity and nuance. The introduction of a high-profile amicus brief on behalf of the petitioners has added a new dimension to their case, shifting some of the focus from pure legal doctrine to broader principles of foreign policy and separation of powers.

My cumulative beliefs are now:

*   **The Central Conflict - The Nature of "Consent" (Stable):** This remains the core doctrinal dispute.
    *   **Petitioners' View (Stable):** Consent can be statutorily "deemed" based on a defendant's conduct, per *Mallory v. Norfolk S. Ry. Co.* The PLO/PA's terror-related payments are a compelling basis for such deemed consent.
    *   **Respondents' Counter (Stable):** This is a "legislative fiat." True consent requires a voluntary submission to jurisdiction, as in *Ins. Corp. of Ireland*. They distinguish *Mallory* by highlighting the absence of a reciprocal bargain (the PLO/PA receives no benefit from the U.S. for the conduct that triggers jurisdiction).

*   **The Constitutional Debate - 5th vs. 14th Amendment (Stable):** This foundational disagreement is unchanged.
    *   **Petitioners' View (Stable):** The 14th Amendment's *International Shoe* standard, rooted in interstate federalism, does not limit the federal government's sovereign power under the 5th Amendment, especially in foreign affairs.
    *   **Respondents' Counter (Stable):** The due process protections of both amendments are fundamentally the same regarding personal jurisdiction.

*   **The Battle over Originalism (Stable):** The historical arguments remain in direct opposition.
    *   **Petitioners' Originalism (Stable):** The Fifth Amendment, as originally understood, imposed no territorial limits on Congress's power to grant jurisdiction to federal courts.
    *   **Respondents' Counter-Originalism (Stable):** Founding-era jurisprudence, informed by natural law and jurists like Joseph Story, recognized territorial limits as a core part of due process, citing cases like *Picquet v. Swan*.

*   **The Separation of Powers Clash (Expanded and Contested):** What was previously a one-sided "off-ramp" for the respondents is now a contested battleground.
    *   **Respondents' View (Stable):** The PSJVTA violates the separation of powers by commanding the judiciary to "deem" a jurisdictional fact (consent) to be true, stripping courts of their fact-finding function, akin to the issue in *United States v. Klein*.
    *   **Petitioners' Counter (New Information from Amicus):** The Second Circuit's decision represents a judicial encroachment on the political branches' exclusive constitutional authority over foreign policy and national security. The amicus brief from former Secretary of State Mike Pompeo argues that counterterrorism policy is "wholly confided" to Congress and the Executive (*Chi. & S. Air Lines, Inc.*), and courts should give extreme deference to their chosen methods, like the PSJVTA.

*   **New Dimension - The Foreign Policy & National Security Frame (New Information):** The Pompeo amicus brief forcefully injects a policy-based argument for upholding the law. It contends that the PSJVTA is a vital and "considered" tool for U.S. counterterrorism, designed to deter the "pay-for-slay" program and disrupt terrorist financing. This argument frames the case not as a technical due process question, but as a matter of national security where the judiciary's role is "highly constrained" (*Trump v. Hawaii*).

*   **Updated Prediction Model:** The respondents' direct rebuttals to the petitioners' core due process arguments remain legally robust. However, the petitioners' case is now bolstered by a powerful alternative framework of judicial deference to the political branches in foreign affairs. This new argument could be particularly persuasive to certain justices who prioritize executive power and national security. It provides a path for the Court to reverse the Second Circuit without deeply engaging the *Mallory* vs. *International Shoe* debate, instead ruling on broader institutional grounds. My confidence in a victory for the respondents has slightly decreased; the probability distribution has widened to account for the possibility that a majority coalesces around this national security deference argument. The key uncertainty is now a two-level question: 1) Will the Court decide this on narrow due process grounds or broad foreign policy grounds? 2) Within the chosen ground, which side's argument will prevail?
current_beliefs.design_beliefs:
This observation has refined my understanding of the different roles that legal documents play and has led to the development of more sophisticated analytical heuristics. My meta-level framework for legal prediction continues to evolve.

My design beliefs now incorporate these cumulative principles:

*   **Prioritize Primary Source Documents (Stable):** The bedrock principle remains unchanged. The sequential analysis of the case facts, petitioners' brief, respondents' brief, and now an amicus brief, has proven to be the optimal path for building a multi-layered and accurate model of the legal dispute.

*   **Map the Political-Branch Ecosystem (Evolved Heuristic):** My previous heuristic to "Track the Solicitor General" was too narrow. This observation shows that in cases touching on foreign policy or national security, it is crucial to map the arguments from the entire political-branch "ecosystem." This includes the current administration (via the SG), former executive officials (like Secretary Pompeo), and potentially legislative groups. These actors often introduce arguments centered on institutional power and policy that are distinct from, and sometimes more powerful than, the doctrinal arguments of the primary litigants.

*   **Build a Dialectical Map (Validated and Expanded):** The value of mapping point-for-point argumentation is re-confirmed. This observation expands the map's complexity. It's not just Petitioner vs. Respondent on a single issue. It is now clear that there can be competing arguments on the same general principle (e.g., both sides now have a "separation of powers" claim) and different *types* of arguments (e.g., petitioners' legal argument from *Mallory* vs. their policy argument from the amicus brief).

*   **Identify "Off-Ramps" and "Alternative Frameworks" (Evolved Heuristic):** My heuristic to find "off-ramps" (narrower grounds for a decision) is now supplemented by a more powerful concept: searching for "alternative frameworks." The Pompeo brief does not offer a narrow escape; it attempts to reframe the entire case from a due process dispute into a national security deference case. Amicus briefs are therefore not just for reinforcement; they can be strategic attempts to change the lens through which the Court views the central conflict. A key task is now to identify when an amicus is merely supporting an existing argument versus when it is trying to change the game.

*   **Iterative Uncertainty Reduction (Validated and Formalized):** The `Ingest -> Model -> Identify Gap -> Target -> Acquire` loop remains my core validated strategy. Having built a dialectical model from the merits briefs, my next implicit "gap" was understanding the arguments of other influential actors. The search for amicus briefs was a logical next step that successfully acquired information, adding a new and important dimension to my model and further reducing uncertainty about the potential paths to a final decision.

Nos. 24-20 & 24-151 
IN THE
Supreme Court of the United States
_____________________
MIRIAM FULD, ET AL.,
Petitioners, 
v.

UNITED STATES OF AMERICA, 
Petitioner, 
v. 
 PALESTINE LIBERATION ORGANIZATION, ET AL., 
Respondents.

On Writs of Certiorari to the United States Court 
of Appeals for the Second Circuit 
_____________________
BRIEF FOR RESPONDENTS  
_____________________ 
GASSAN A. BALOUL
  Counsel of Record 
MITCHELL R. BERGER
SQUIRE PATTON BOGGS (US) LLP 
2550 M Street, NW 
Washington, D.C. 20037 
(202) 457-6000 
gassan.baloul@squirepb.com 
 February 28, 2025 
     Counsel for Respondents 

i 
QUESTION PRESENTED 
The Promoting Security and Justice for Victims of 
Terrorism Act (PSJVTA) mandates that courts shall 
“deem” that Respondents “have consented” to 
personal jurisdiction in the United States if they 
engage in either of two types of predicate conduct: (i) 
payments relating to Palestinians imprisoned or 
killed as a result of committing overseas attacks 
harming American nationals; or (ii) any actions in the 
United States other than participation in the United 
Nations, meetings with government officials, and 
activities “ancillary” thereto.   
In cases before the PSJVTA, courts uniformly held 
that the payments, which occur entirely outside the 
United States, do not support personal jurisdiction 
because they are not connected to the forum or to 
Plaintiffs’ claims.  For the same reasons, courts held 
that Respondents’ alleged U.S. activities cannot 
support jurisdiction.  Now, under the broad provisions 
of the PSJVTA, Petitioners assert that Respondents 
“consented” to personal jurisdiction in the United 
States by engaging in the same conduct previously 
held insufficient to support the exercise of jurisdiction 
as a matter of due process. 
The question presented is:  
Whether the Second Circuit correctly held that the 
PSJVTA violates due process by requiring courts to 
“deem” that Respondents “have consented” to 
personal jurisdiction based on conduct that cannot 
support a presumption that Respondents have 
submitted to jurisdiction in the United States.

1 
CONSTITUTIONAL AND STATUTORY 
PROVISIONS AT ISSUE 
Relevant constitutional and statutory provisions 
are reproduced in the appendix.  App. 1a-5a.  
INTRODUCTION  
The PSJVTA is the latest legislative attempt to 
undo an unbroken line of cases holding that 
Respondents PA and PLO are not subject to personal 
jurisdiction in the United States for their alleged 
involvement in terrorist attacks in Israel and 
Palestine.  Time and again, courts have held that 
exercising personal jurisdiction over Respondents 
would violate due process because the attacks did not 
target Americans, and Respondents lack any other 
constitutionally-sufficient connection to the United 
States.  Because jurisdictional due process protections 
are rooted in the Constitution, these decisions cannot 
be undone by legislation. 
As the Second Circuit held, the PSJVTA attempts 
an end-run around settled constitutional analysis by 
declaring that Respondents always shall be “deemed” 
to “consent” to personal jurisdiction when they engage 
in the same conduct courts have previously held 
insufficient to support jurisdiction under the Due 
Process Clause.  Pet. App. 25a-38a, 44a. 1   The 
PSJVTA accordingly seeks to elide the constitutional 
boundaries of due process recognized in prior cases.   
The Second Circuit saw through this ruse, 
holding—like every other federal court to consider the 
issue—that “deemed consent” imposed by legislative 
fiat cannot paper over the lack of any constitutionally-
meaningful connection between Respondents, the 
forum, and the conduct that gave rise to Plaintiffs’ 
1 Pet. App. refers to the appendix to Plaintiffs’ petition.  

2 
claims.  As the courts below recognized, the PSJVTA 
only pretends to replace traditional due process 
“minimum 
contacts” 
analysis 
with 
“consent.”  
Respondents have not taken any actions that could be 
understood as submission to personal jurisdiction: 
they did not sign a contract agreeing to jurisdiction, 
they did not accept any benefit from the Government 
conditioned on submission to jurisdiction, and they 
did not take any other actions signifying their express 
or implied agreement to litigate these disputes in the 
United States.  Rather, Respondents have repeatedly 
and successfully challenged personal jurisdiction on 
facts nearly identical to those here. 
The court of appeals scrupulously followed this 
Court’s guidance in Mallory v. Norfolk S. Ry. Co., 600 
U.S. 122 (2023) and Ins. Corp. of Ireland, Ltd. v. 
Compagnie des Bauxites de Guinee (“Bauxites”), 456 
U.S. 694 (1982) in holding that Respondents’ conduct 
does not meet due process standards for consent-
based jurisdiction.  Respondents have not taken any 
action that manifests submission to jurisdiction under 
Bauxites.  And the PSJVTA does not grant any benefit 
to Respondents in exchange for submission to 
jurisdiction that could bring this case closer to 
Mallory.  The court of appeals thus explained that 
“Congress cannot take conduct otherwise insufficient 
to support an inference of consent” and “brand it as 
‘consent.’”  Pet. App. 44a.   
Under Mallory, neither form of conduct relied upon 
by Petitioners—making payments in Palestine and 
conducting UN-related activities in the United 
States—signals Respondents’ submission to personal 
jurisdiction in the United States.  As to the payments, 
that is because the United States does not have 
antecedent authority to permit them in the first 
place—just as Pennsylvania could not offer a company 

3 
the right to do business in New Jersey in exchange for 
consent to jurisdiction in Pennsylvania.  As to the 
activity prong, the PSJVTA specifically excludes 
“official” UN business and “ancillary” activities, does 
not 
waive 
or 
withdraw 
preexisting 
statutory 
restrictions on Respondents’ activities in the United 
States, and does not permit any U.S. activity at all by 
Respondents.  In turn, since at least the PSJVTA’s 
effective date, Respondents perform no U.S. activities 
outside the UN sphere (whether those activities are 
denominated “official” UN activity or “ancillary” 
activity).  The PSJVTA merely avoids interfering with 
the United Nations’ preexisting authority to grant 
international actors “invitee” status. 
Allowing Congress to impose “consent” on 
Respondents in these circumstances would swallow 
the due process test and eviscerate the meaning of 
consent.  If due process required nothing more than 
notice, then nothing would stop Congress from 
decreeing that a defendant shall be “deemed” to have 
“consented” to personal jurisdiction by engaging in 
any activity anywhere in the world.  These are not 
merely theoretical concerns.  That is precisely what 
the PSJVTA purports to do here.  The Government’s 
argument that such jurisdiction could satisfy 
“fundamental fairness” under a “flexible” due process 
standard that “depends on the type of actor involved” 
(Gov’t Br. 5, 25), underscores Petitioners’ failure to 
offer any meaningful or consistent guardrails.   
Nor can the PSJVTA be upheld as an exercise of 
the enumerated power to punish extraterritorial 
offenses.  Although Petitioners significantly overread 
the scope of that power, the bottom line is that 
Congress cannot impose personal jurisdiction as a 
punishment or sanction.  This Court’s decisions hold 
that personal jurisdiction must be independently 

4 
established consistent with due process minimum 
contacts even when Congress has the power to enact 
statutes with extraterritorial substantive reach. 
Nor does Plaintiffs’ historical argument save the 
statute.  The founders believed due process of law 
protected the natural rights of individuals, and early 
American courts regularly held that personal 
jurisdiction protections were safeguarded from 
Congressional interference.  Neither the payments 
nor Respondents’ alleged “official” and “ancillary” UN-
related actions are within the territorial authority of 
the United States.  The Framers never imagined that 
Congress would have power to create jurisdiction over 
foreign actors for conduct not within the territorial 
limits of, and not directed at, the United States.   
STATEMENT 
The PA is the domestic government of parts of the 
West Bank and the Gaza Strip, collectively referred to 
as “Palestine.”  Pet. App. 6a.  The PA provides 
conventional government services, including public 
safety, healthcare, transportation, a judicial system, 
and public schools, with over 155,000 government 
employees.  Id. at 143a-44a.  Under the Oslo Accords, 
the PLO conducts Palestinian foreign affairs, 
including operating its mission to the United Nations.  
Id. at 6a; see also JA 65-68 (State Dept. Statement of 
Interest).  The United States does not recognize 
Respondents as sovereign.  Gov’t Br. 3; Pet. App. 153a.   
Respondents 
are 
currently 
forbidden 
from 
operating in the United States.  See 22 U.S.C. §§ 
5201(b), 5202; Palestinian Anti-Terrorism Act of 2006, 
Pub. L. No. 109-446, § 7(a)2, 120 Stat. 3318 (22 U.S.C. 
2 Plaintiffs erroneously cite Section 7(b), rather than Section 
7(a), of the Palestinian Anti-Terrorism Act, which is the 
provision cited by the Second Circuit.  Pls. Br. 45 n.11 (citing Pet. 

5 
§ 2378b note); United States v. PLO, 695 F. Supp. 1456, 
1465-68, 1471 (S.D.N.Y. 1988).  An invitation from the 
United Nations affords the sole exception, permitting 
Palestine’s UN mission to conduct activities relating 
to its role as a UN Non-Member State “invitee.”  Pet. 
App. 10a n.2.  The PLO had a diplomatic mission in 
Washington, D.C., but that office closed in 2018, 
before 
the 
PSJVTA 
became 
effective. 
 
Ibid.
Respondents have no other offices and conduct no 
activities in the United States.  Id. at 28a, 64a. 
A.
Courts Unanimously Agree Respondents 
Are Not Subject to Personal Jurisdiction 
in the United States. 
Because Respondents’ alleged actions do not have 
any constitutionally-meaningful connection to the 
United States, federal courts have long held that 
exercising personal jurisdiction over Respondents for 
alleged attacks in Israel and Palestine would violate 
due process.  In Sokolow, Plaintiffs brought Anti-
Terrorism Act clai

MITCHELL R. BERGER
SQUIRE PATTON BOGGS (US) LLP 
2550 M Street, NW 
Washington, D.C. 20037 
(202) 457-6000 
gassan.baloul@squirepb.com 
 February 28, 2025 
     Counsel for Respondents 

i 
QUESTION PRESENTED 
The Promoting Security and Justice for Victims of 
Terrorism Act (PSJVTA) mandates that courts shall 
“deem” that Respondents “have consented” to 
personal jurisdiction in the United States if they 
engage in either of two types of predicate conduct: (i) 
payments relating to Palestinians imprisoned or 
killed as a result of committing overseas attacks 
harming American nationals; or (ii) any actions in the 
United States other than participation in the United 
Nations, meetings with government officials, and 
activities “ancillary” thereto.   
In cases before the PSJVTA, courts uniformly held 
that the payments, which occur entirely outside the 
United States, do not support personal jurisdiction 
because they are not connected to the forum or to 
Plaintiffs’ claims.  For the same reasons, courts held 
that Respondents’ alleged U.S. activities cannot 
support jurisdiction.  Now, under the broad provisions 
of the PSJVTA, Petitioners assert that Respondents 
“consented” to personal jurisdiction in the United 
States by engaging in the same conduct previously 
held insufficient to support the exercise of jurisdiction 
as a matter of due process. 
The question presented is:  
Whether the Second Circuit correctly held that the 
PSJVTA violates due process by requiring courts to 
“deem” that Respondents “have consented” to 
personal jurisdiction based on conduct that cannot 
support a presumption that Respondents have 
submitted to jurisdiction in the United States.   

ii
