Burnham v. Super Ct. of Cal., Cty. of Marin,  
495 U.S. 604 (1990) .......................................... 10–12 
Carnival Cruise Lines, Inc. v. Shute,  
499 U.S. 585 (1991)  ......................................... 2, 4–5 
Daimler AG v. Bauman,  
571 U.S. 117 (2014) .................................................. 9 
Ins. Corp. of Ireland Ltd. v. Compagnie des 
Bauxites de Guinee,  
456 U.S. 694 (1982) ...................................... 2–3, 6–8 
Holder v. Humanitarian Law Project,  
561 U.S. 1 (2010)  ................................................... 10 
Mallory v. Norfolk Southern Railway Co.,  
600 U.S. 122 (2023) .............................. 1–3, 6–12, 14 
M/S Bremen v. Zapata Off-Shore Co.,  
407 U.S. 1 (1972) ...................................................... 4 
Shaffer v. Heitner,  
433 U.S. 186 (1977) ................................................ 12 

 
 
 
 
 
iii 
 
 
TradeComet.com LLC v. Google, Inc.,  
647 F.3d 472 (2d Cir. 2011) ..................................... 2 
Waldman v. Palestine Liberation Org.,  
835 F.3d 317 (2d Cir. 2016), cert denied sub nom. 
Sokolow v. Palestine Liberation Org.,  
584 U.S. 915 (2018) .......................................... 11–12 
York v. Texas, 
137 U.S. 15 (1890) .................................................... 2 
Ziglar v. Abbasi,  
582 U.S. 120 (2017) ................................................ 10 
Statutes 
10 Del. C. § 3114(a) ................................................... 12 
Anti-Terrorism Act of 1987,  
Pub. L. No. 100-204, 101 Stat. 1406 .................... 2, 9 
Anti-Terrorism Clarification Act of 2018,  
Pub. L. No. 115-253, 132 Stat. 3183 ................ 11, 12 
Promoting Security and Justice for Victims of 
Terrorism Act of 2019, Pub. L. No. 116-94,   
133 Stat. 3082 (2019) ............. 1, 3–5, 7–8, 10–12, 14 
Other Authorities 
Aaron D. Simowitz, Federal Personal Jurisdiction 
and Constitutional Authority, 56 N.Y.U. J. Int’l 
L. & Pol. 345 (2024) ................................................ 14 
Aaron D. Simowitz, Jurisdiction as Dialogue, 
52 N.Y.U. J. Int’l L. & Pol. 485 (2020) ............ 12–13 

 
 
 
 
 
iv 
 
 
Google Terms of Service, 
https://policies.google.com/terms?hl=en-US (last 
accessed February 3, 2025) ...................................... 2 
John F. Coyle, “Contractually Valid” Forum 
Selection Clauses,  
108 Iowa L. Rev. 127 (2022)..................................... 4 
John F. Coyle & Robin J. Effron, Forum Selection 
Clauses, Non-Signatories, and Personal 
Jurisdiction, 97 Notre Dame L. Rev. 187 (2021) .... 4 
Restatement (Fourth) of Foreign Relations Law 
§ 413 (Am. L. Inst. 2018) .......................................... 9 
Robin J. Effron & Aaron D. Simowitz,  
The Long Arm of Consent, 80 N.Y.U. Ann. Surv. 
Am. L. 179 (2024) ......................................... 1, 10–12 
Stephen E. Sachs, The Unlimited Jurisdiction of 
the Federal Courts, 106 Va. L. Rev. 1703 (2020) .. 14 

 
 
 
 
 
1 
 
 
INTEREST OF AMICI CURIAE 
Amici are professors of law who have taught and 
written about civil procedure and conflict of laws. 
They have an interest in the sound development of the 
Court’s doctrine in these fields. A list of amici and 
their academic positions is set forth in the Appendix.1 
SUMMARY OF THE ARGUMENT 
This Court reaffirmed in Mallory v. Norfolk 
Southern Railway Co. that “express or implied 
consent” remains a constitutionally sound basis for 
establishing personal jurisdiction over a defendant, 
and that consent may be given “by word or deed.” 
600 U.S. 122, 138 (2023) (plurality) (emphasis added); 
see also id. at 153 (Alito, J., concurring in part and 
concurring in the judgment); see generally Robin J. 
Effron & Aaron D. Simowitz, The Long Arm of 
Consent, 80 N.Y.U. Ann. Surv. Am. L. 179 (2024).  In 
the decision below, the Second Circuit nonetheless 
held that the conduct deemed to constitute consent 
under the PSJVTA “cannot support a fair and 
reasonable inference of the defendants’ voluntary 
agreement to proceed in a federal forum,” and “lack[s] 
any of the indicia of valid consent previously 
recognized in the case law.” Pet. App. 26a. 
In so holding, the Second Circuit effectively 
concluded that, although a party may validly consent 
to personal jurisdiction in a given forum by 
 
1 No counsel for any party authored this brief in whole or in 
part, and no person or entity other than amicus or his counsel 
funded its preparation or submission. Sup. Ct. R. 37.6. 

 
 
 
 
 
2 
 
 
purchasing a cruise ship ticket with a forum-selection 
clause tucked into three pages of fine print on the 
ticket’s back, Carnival Cruise Lines, Inc. v. Shute, 
499 U.S. 585 (1991), engaging in discovery abuses, 
Ins. Corp. of Ireland Ltd. v. Compagnie des Bauxites 
de Guinee, 456 U.S. 694 (1982), or mistakenly 
entering a general appearance, York v. Texas, 137 
U.S. 15 (1890), the same result does not obtain for 
sophisticated, well-counseled entities fully apprised of 
the consequences of their actions. As a result, the 
decision below gives more protection to defendants 
that the elected branches concluded should be suable 
under the Anti-Terrorism Act than it does to users of 
Google products who are required to adjudicate their 
disputes in California, regardless of where their 
disputes arose.2 Such a result cannot be reconciled 
with this Court’s precedents.  
To that end, the Court does not need to analyze 
how the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments’ Due 
Process Clauses might impose different limitations on 
the exercise of personal jurisdiction; instead, Mallory 
and basic, already settled propositions about the Fifth 
Amendment control the outcome of this case. Mallory 
sets the standard for personal jurisdiction under the 
Fourteenth Amendment, and all agree that the Fifth 
Amendment is at least as generous to plaintiffs as the 
 
2 See Google Terms of Service, https://policies.google.com/ 
terms?hl=en-US (last accessed February 3, 2025) (“[A]ll disputes 
arising out of or relating to these terms . . . will be resolved 
exclusively in the federal or state courts of Santa Clara County, 
California, USA, and you and Google consent to personal 
jurisdiction in those courts.”); see also TradeComet.com LLC v. 
Google, Inc., 647 F.3d 472 (2d Cir. 2011). 

 
 
 
 
 
3 
 
 
Fourteenth Amendment in that context. Therefore, 
because the PSJVTA satisfies Mallory, assertions of 
personal jurisdiction under the Act must satisfy the 
Fifth Amendment. The Court need go no further in 
reversing the decision below. 
Separately, the Court has every reason to defer to 
the decision of the elected branches in matters 
implicating foreign affairs and the regulation of 
terrorism, in which judicial deference is at its zenith, 
especially where the action of the elected branches 
came in direct response to prior judicial decisions in 
this case. The Second Circuit’s jurisdictional decision 
undercut Congress’s authority in this area and, in 
doing so, ignored law that already polices Congress’s 
power to regulate international terrorism. In this 
case, separation of powers principles warrant 
heightened deference to the elected branches, not the 
heightened skepticism with which the Second Circuit 
viewed the PSJVTA.  
ARGUMENT 
I. 
The 
Decision 
Below 
Misconstrues 
This Court’s “Consent” Precedents 
As the Mallory plurality explained, under this 
Court’s precedents “a variety of ‘actions of the 
defendant’ 
that 
may 
seem 
like 
technicalities 
nonetheless can ‘amount to a legal submission to the 
jurisdiction of the court.’” 600 U.S. at 145 (plurality) 
(quoting Bauxites, 456 U.S. at 704–05) (offering as 
examples “[f]ailing to comply with certain pre-trial 
orders, signing a contract with a forum selection 

 
 
 
 
 
4 
 
 
clause, [and] accepting an in-state benefit with 
jurisdictional strings attached”). The PSJVTA fits 
comfortably within these parameters of consent-based 
jurisdiction. 
A. The Court’s consent-based personal-jurisdiction 
precedents have not always been decided on 
constitutional grounds.  For instance, in Shute, which 
analyzed the enforceability of a forum selection 
clause, the Court invoked the canon of constitutional 
avoidance and concluded that, because the forum-
selection clause was “dispositive . . . , we need not 
consider petitioner’s constitutional argument as to 
personal jurisdiction.” 499 U.S. at 589–90; see also 
M/S Bremen v. Zapata Off-Shore Co., 407 U.S. 1, 10–
11 (1972) (forum selection clauses “should be enforced 
unless enforcement is shown by the resisting party to 
be ‘unreasonable’ under the circumstances”). 
Following 
Shute, 
consent-based 
personal-
jurisdiction has been viewed through a maximalist 
lens, with courts commonly upholding forum-selection 
clauses against parties “who have ‘consented’ to the 
forum via a boilerplate agreement that they may 
neither read nor comprehend.” John F. Coyle & Robin 
J. Effron, Forum Selection Clauses, Non-Signatories, 
and Personal Jurisdiction, 97 Notre Dame L. Rev. 
187, 230 (2021). Shrinkwrap, clickwrap, and end user 
license 
agreements 
containing 
forum-selection 
clauses have multiplied exponentially, yet their 
“reasonableness” is almost always upheld. John F. 
Coyle, “Contractually Valid” Forum Selection Clauses, 
108 Iowa L. Rev. 127, 155–56 (2022).  

 
 
 
 
 
5 
 
 
The decision below dismissed Shute as a case 
“enforc[ing] 
the 
express 
jurisdiction-conferring 
language 
of 
a 
contract 
after 
accounting 
for 
considerations of notice and fundamental fairness,” 
rather than one involving the “inference” of consent. 
Pet. App. 25a. But many post-Shute lower-court 
decisions simply dispense with the need to conduct 
any constitutional due process analysis when 
presented with an enforceable forum selection clause. 
See Coyle & Effron, supra, at 232–34 (collecting 
cases). Either way, treating forum-selection clauses as 
the Second Circuit did—as merely another contract 
provision to be enforced—fails to recognize the 
significant constitutional assumptions embedded in 
their enforceability. 
In that regard, the Second Circuit wrongly rejected 
the 
Fuld 
Petitioners’ 
argument 
that 
the 
constitutionality of the PSJVTA follows a fortiori from 
Shute. Millions of Americans “consent” to jurisdiction 
every day by dint of continuing to use products and 
services whose terms and conditions contain forum-
selection clauses. A consumer’s continued use of such 
products or services is a continued manifestation of 
consent to personal jurisdiction by deed; and it is her 
intentional conduct of continued use that gives rise to 
consent rather than any affirmative act with respect 
to the forum-selection clause generally. If such 
boilerplate provisions satisfy constitutional due 
process, then a federal statute giving notice to 
sophisticated, well-counseled defendants that their 
engagement in specified conduct will be deemed 

 
 
 
 
 
6 
 
 
consent to personal jurisdiction must be constitutional 
as well. 
B. The decision below went equally astray in 
drawing an artificial distinction between “deemed 
consent,” which it determined required “some 
exchange of benefits,” and “certain litigation-related 
conduct,” which it described vaguely as “[an]other 
means of demonstrating consent.” Pet. App. 36a n.13. 
In so doing, it ignored the central principle that “[t]he 
actions of the defendant may amount to a legal 
submission to the jurisdiction of the court, whether 
voluntary or not.” Bauxites, 456 U.S. at 704–05 
(emphasis added). In Bauxites, the Court held that 
due process under the Fourteenth Amendment is not 
violated when courts equate the failure to comply with 
jurisdictional discovery orders with a “an admission of 
the want of merit in the asserted defense” of personal 
jurisdiction. 456 U.S. at 705. In that sense, adverse 
inferences 
arising 
from 
litigation 
conduct 
fit 
comfortably within the consent regime approved by 
the Court in Mallory, and it is unsurprising that 
Mallory drew so extensively on Bauxites to drive home 
the point that “‘actions of the defendant’ that may 
seem like technicalities nonetheless can ‘amount to a 
legal submission to the jurisdiction of a court.’” 
Mallory, 600 U.S. at 146 (quoting Bauxites, 456 U.S. 
at 704–05)); id. at 148 (Jackson, J., concurring) 
(discussing Bauxites).3  
 
3 The distinction drawn by the Second Circuit between 
conduct within litigation and conduct without (Pet. App. 32a–
 

 
 
 
 
 
7 
 
 
II. 
The Reasoning of Mallory Answers 
This Case 
Despite the Second Circuit’s disavowal of Mallory, 
see Pet. App. 32a–35a, the Court can decide the 
instant case on the authority of Mallory and basic, 
undisputed assumptions about the Fifth Amendment.  
A. As Mallory instructs, “‘express or implied 
consent’ 
can 
continue 
to 
ground 
personal 
jurisdiction—and consent may be manifested in 
various ways by word or deed.” 600 U.S. at 138 (2023) 
(plurality) (emphasis added); see id. at 153 (Alito, J., 
concurring in part and concurring in the judgment). 
This case differs from Mallory in the sense that it 
addresses consent by deed, not word, and that the law 
is an act of Congress, not a state legislature; 
otherwise, there is not much daylight between the two 
statutes.  
The Second Circuit’s attempt to wave away 
Mallory makes no sense: “The Pennsylvania law at 
issue in Mallory did not involve an actual bargain or 
a ‘voluntary agreement,’ . . . between the state and 
each company,” because Norfolk Southern was 
deemed to have consented to personal jurisdiction; its 
 
36a) is difficult to understand except as an attempt to mitigate 
the Second Circuit’s difficulty with reconciling its top-line 
conclusion with Bauxites. See infra at 8. Consent deemed 
ex ante—especially as to sophisticated parties closely tracking 
the enactment of the PSJVTA—provides clear and unambiguous 
notice, whereas consent deemed by litigation conduct may well 
rest with the broad discretion of a trial court. See, e.g., Bauxites, 
456 U.S. at 707. The former approach is far more consistent with 
the ordinary meaning of “consent.” 

 
 
 
 
 
8 
 
 
registration to do business in Pennsylvania pursuant 
to one statute brought it within the ambit of a 
separate statute deeming registration as a foreign 
corporation a “sufficient basis” for the exercise of 
general 
personal 
jurisdiction. 
Pet. 
App. 
244a 
(Menashi, J., dissenting from denial of rehearing  
en banc).  
To that end, the “reciprocal benefit” rationale set 
forth in the decision below cannot be reconciled with 
this Court’s decision in Bauxites (among others), 
requiring the Second Circuit to invent the separate 
category of “litigation-related conduct.” See supra 
at 6. But nothing in Mallory suggests that courts 
should awkwardly parse different categories of 
consent. Indeed, the disagreement among the Second 
Circuit is evidence enough that this Court should not 
insert itself into determining whether consent is the 
product of a sufficiently “reciprocal” “bargain” or 
whether a particular statute, forum-selection clause, 
or discovery abuse manifests “a reasonable inference 
of consent.”  
B. The PSJVTA satisfies the Mallory standard.  
Indeed, the Act presents an easier constitutional 
question, because it does not implicate concerns 
present in cases in which personal jurisdiction is 
being exercised pursuant to state (rather than federal) 
law. In this case, there are no dormant commerce 
clause or other federalism concerns. Cf. Mallory, 
600 U.S. at 157 (Alito, J., concurring in part and 
concurring in the judgment). Likewise, unlike the 
Pennsylvania statute at issue in Mallory, the PSJTVA 

 
 
 
 
 
9 
 
 
does not provide for general, “all purpose” jurisdiction 
over defendants. Cf. Daimler AG v. Bauman, 571 U.S. 
117 (2014). On the contrary, the PSJTVA restricts its 
application to claims (i) brought under the Anti-
Terrorism Act (ii) by U.S. nationals (iii) against 
specifically named defendants who (iv) continue to 
engage in conduct specified by the statute.4 It does not 
resurrect a “blanket claim of authority over 
controversies with no connection to the [United 
States].” Mallory, 600 U.S. at 170 (Barrett, J., 
dissenting). 
Nor does the PSJTVA prompt international comity 
concerns that have commanded attention in other 
situations. See, e.g., Daimler, 571 U.S. at 140–42. 
International 
law 
clearly 
recognizes 
a 
state’s 
prerogative to prescribe law governing terrorism, 
“even if no specific connection exists between the state 
and the persons or conduct being regulated.” 
Restatement (Fourth) of Foreign Relations Law § 413. 
III. 
Deference To The Elected Branches 
And Constitutional Departmentalism 
Require Reversal 
Should the Court consider it necessary to analyze 
differences between the Due Process Clauses of the 
Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments, the proper frame 
of reference is constitutional deference to the elected 
branches. 
The 
decision 
below 
erred 
in 
this 
fundamental respect, showing disdain for the 
 
4 The constitutionality of “special” legislation in the context 
of federal statutes giving relief to victims of terrorism is settled. 
Bank Markazi v. Peterson, 578 U.S. 212 (2016). 

 
 
 
 
 
10 
 
 
judgment of the elected branches in a case implicating 
foreign affairs, an area in which deference to the 
elected branches is ordinarily at its zenith. E.g., 
Ziglar v. Abbasi, 582 U.S. 120, 142 (2017); Holder v. 
Humanitarian Law Project, 561 U.S. 1, 33–34 (2010). 
A. “[T]he Second Circuit’s decision does not merely 
ignore that the elected branches interpret the 
Constitution. The Court’s decision rejects the notion 
that the elected branches’ judgment is even relevant.” 
Long Arm of Consent at 247. In holding that “[a] 
prospective defendant’s activities do not signify 
consent to personal jurisdiction simply because 
Congress has labeled them as such,” Pet. App. 21a, the 
Second Circuit treated the PSJVTA as a sort of 
legislative aggrandizement of what it saw as the 
judicial branch’s exclusive authority to define the 
limits of personal jurisdiction. This was error.   
Both the Mallory plurality and dissent treated 
Justice Scalia’s opinion in Burnham v. Super. Ct. of 
Cal., 495 U.S. 604 (1990)—the plurality opinion as 
well as Parts II.D and III—as the appropriate frame 
for analyzing consent and other traditional bases of 
jurisdiction. See Mallory, 600 U.S. at 139–41 
(plurality); id. at 171–76 (Barrett, J., dissenting). In 
Burnham, 
Justice 
Scalia 
suggested 
that 
the 
“desirability or fairness of the prevailing in-state 
service rule” should be left to the “judgment [of] the 
legislatures that are free to amend it,” characterizing 
due process as “that process which American society . 
. . , which expresses its judgments in the laws of 
self-interested States—has traditionally considered 

 
 
 
 
 
11 
 
 
‘due.’” 495 U.S. at 621, 627 n.5. (opinion of Scalia, J.). 
That deference to legislative judgment was carried 
forward by the Mallory plurality and dissent alike. 
See Long Arm of Consent at 214. 
A fortiori, “[t]he federal legislature has an even 
stronger claim to interpret the U.S. Constitution 
when 
it 
enacts 
federal 
consent-to-jurisdiction 
statutes.” Id. at 185. Congress’s “interpretations are 
entitled to independent weight under theories of 
constitutional departmentalism,” which, however 
they may differ in their details, contend that “the 
constitutional interpretive authority of the federal 
elected branches is at its height when (i) the federal 
elected branches have engaged in actual, explicit 
constitutional reasoning and (ii) where the nature of 
the underlying right is unsettled.” Id. at 248–49. With 
the Court having explicitly reserved the question 
whether the constraints on personal jurisdiction are 
coterminous 
under 
the 
Fifth 
and 
Fourteenth 
Amendments in Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. v. Super. 
Ct. of Cal., 582 U.S. 255, 268–69 (2017), the detailed 
findings of Congress in enacting the PSJVTA are 
entitled to substantial deference.  
B. Similar weight should be accorded the judgment 
of Congress in passing the PSJVTA in explicit 
response to decisions dismissing the Fuld and 
Sokolow cases for want of personal jurisdiction, just 
as an earlier Congress passed the Antiterrorism 
Clarification Act (ATCA) in response to Waldman v. 
Palestine Liberation Org., 835 F.3d 317 (2d Cir. 2016), 

 
 
 
 
 
12 
 
 
cert denied sub nom. Sokolow v. Palestine Liberation 
Org., 584 U.S. 915 (2018).  
This Court has often looked to the judgment of the 
elected branches when considering traditional bases 
of jurisdiction. For instance, two great pre-Mallory 
precedents, Shaffer v. Heitner, 433 U.S. 186 (1977), 
and Burnham took different approaches, but plainly 
agreed that the judgment of the elected branches 
matters. See Long Arm of Consent at 217–20. Shaffer 
was careful to note that its result might have differed 
if Delaware had “enacted a statute that treats 
acceptance of a directorship as consent to jurisdiction 
in the State.” 433 U.S. at 216. And the Delaware 
General Assembly enacted just such a statute within 
two weeks of the Shaffer decision, see 10 Del. C. 
§ 3114(a), 
which 
has 
consistently 
survived 
constitutional scrutiny. See Aaron D. Simowitz, 
Jurisdiction as Dialogue, 52 N.Y.U. J. Int’l L. & Pol. 
485, 511–13 (2020). Though Justice Scalia’s plurality 
in Burnham turned away from some aspects of 
Shaffer, it also placed great weight on the unanimous 
judgment of state legislatures not to remove 
“tag jurisdiction” from their long-arm statutes. 495 
U.S. at 627. 
Congress’s 
response 
to 
generally 
applicable 
judicially created limitations on personal jurisdiction, 
in the form of statutes like the ATCA and the 
PSJVTA, may be best characterized as a prime 
example of the elected branches engaged in an 
ongoing dialogue with the judicial branch as to 
legislative priorities that require courts to engage 

 
 
 
 
 
13 
 
 
with the elected branches’ own claims to interpreting 
the Constitution. See Jurisdiction as Dialogue at 527–
31; id. at 528 (“[T]here is good reason to think that 
[the regulatory priorities of the elected branches] 
should 
inform 
the 
underlying 
structure 
of 
jurisdiction.”).  
Yet the decision below refused to engage with 
these considerations at all—a point not lost on the 
elected branches. See No. 24-20, Brief Amici Curiae of 
Sen. Charles Grassley, et al. in Support of Certiorari, 
at 23 (“In the end, the lower court’s constitutional 
analysis amounts to little else beyond a disagreement 
between one circuit court and Congress itself on 
complex questions of foreign policy—including the 
proper way to conduct an anti-terror campaign[.]”); 
No. 24-20, Brief Amicus Curiae of Secretary Mike 
Pompeo in Support of Certiorari, at 3 (“The decision 
below—invalidating [an antiterrorism policy] created 
in coordination with the State Department and 
enacted with bipartisan support—frustrates the 
political branches’ considered attempt to minimize the 
terror risk overseas.”); cf. No. 24-20, Brief Amicus 
Curiae of the U.S. House of Representatives in 
Support of Certiorari, at 8 (“If the Fifth Amendment’s 
Due Process Clause precludes Congress from 
providing American victims of international terrorism 
an effective civil remedy in most circumstances, this 
Court should be the one to say so.”). 
Given these considerations, one need not take a 
maximalist view of the Fifth Amendment’s Due 
Process Clause to appreciate that the Second Circuit 

 
 
 
 
 
14 
 
 
went astray in holding it coterminous with that of the 
Fourteenth Amendment. Cf. Stephen E. Sachs, The 
Unlimited Jurisdiction of the Federal Courts, 106 Va. 
L. Rev. 1703, 1710 (2020) (“[A]s to the scope of the 
courts’ 
territorial 
jurisdiction, 
the 
[Fifth 
Amendment’s Due Process] Clause has nothing to 
say.”). Although the judicial branch has long served as 
an arbiter of interstate federalism and state 
assertions of jurisdiction, it is not the “arbiter of 
foreign relations.” Aaron D. Simowitz, Federal 
Personal Jurisdiction and Constitutional Authority, 
56 N.Y.U. J. Int’l L. & Pol. 345, 362 (2024).  
Taken together, the institutional competence of 
the elected branches to make decisions in the field of 
foreign relations, the deference owed those decisions, 
and appreciation for the elected branches’ exercise of 
constitutional interpretation require that the elected 
branches of the federal government should generally 
be competent to authorize personal jurisdiction 
without the need for judicial scrutiny under the Due 
Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment. See id. at 
363. To the extent the Court does not consider the 
Second Circuit’s misapplication of Mallory and this 
Court’s other consent-based personal jurisdiction 
caselaw conclusive, proper consideration of the elected 
branches’ interpretive and structural authority favors 
the constitutionality of the PSJVTA.  
 
 

 
 
 
 
 
15 
 
 
CONCLUSION 
The decisions below should be reversed.  
Respectfully submitted, 
KEVIN D. BENISH 
   Counsel of Record 
PATRICK J. WOODS 
HOLWELL SHUSTER  
   & GOLDBERG LLP 
    
 
 
              425 Lexington Avenue 
 
 
 
 
14th Floor 
 
 
 
 
New York, NY 10017 
 
 
 
 
(646) 837-8349 
 
kbenish@hsgllp.com 
 
Counsel for Amici Curiae  
Scholars of Civil Procedure  
and Conflict of Laws 
    
February 4, 2025

i

APPENDIX A—LIST OF AMICI CURIAE .............. 1a

current_beliefs.task_beliefs:
My second attempt to acquire the brief for the United States as petitioner has failed, returning the exact same document as my first attempt: the brief for the private petitioners, Miriam Fuld, et al. This repeated failure means my central uncertainty remains entirely unresolved. My knowledge of the case's legal landscape is static, and my ability to predict the outcome has not advanced.

My cumulative beliefs are:

*   **The Central Conflict - The Nature of "Consent" (Stable & Unchanged):** The core legal tension remains a balanced scale. The Fuld petitioners' brief, which I have now received twice, consistently argues that this is a stronger case for jurisdiction-by-consent than *Mallory v. Norfolk S. Ry. Co.* This reinforces my understanding of their position but does not change the fundamental balance, as the respondents' likely counter-arguments (relying on *Ins. Corp. of Ireland* and the lack of a "reciprocal bargain") are still equally plausible and potent without the government's intervention.

*   **The Constitutional Debate - 5th vs. 14th Amendment (Stable & Unchanged):** The petitioners' strategy of distinguishing the Fifth Amendment's constraints on the federal government from the Fourteenth's constraints on states is a fixed and known quantity. The table of contents from the Fuld brief ("The Second Circuit’s Conflation Of Fifth And Fourteenth Amendment Standards Disregards Interstate Federalism") confirms this is a central pillar of their case. My model of this debate is stable.

*   **The Battle over Originalism (Stable & Unchanged):** The historical arguments are set. The Fuld brief's first major argument ("The Fifth Amendment’s Original Public Meaning Imposed No Limit On Personal Jurisdiction") validates my map of their originalist claims. This part of the dialectic is fully understood from the petitioners' side.

*   **The Separation of Powers Clash (Stable & Unchanged):** This secondary battleground remains in place. I have a clear view of the petitioners' and respondents' arguments, but the Executive Branch's view—a crucial element in any separation of powers analysis—is still a complete black box.

*   **The Solicitor General as the Decisive Variable (Hypothesis Stable, Uncertainty Entrenched):** My hypothesis that the SG's brief is the key inflection point is not only unchanged but is now underscored by the frustration of two failed attempts to acquire it. The critical questions I previously identified remain entirely unanswered, and my inability to answer them is now a confirmed procedural problem, not just a temporary information gap.
    *   **Unresolved Doctrinal Alignment:** I still do not know which side of the *Mallory* / *Ins. Corp. of Ireland* debate the U.S. government will support. This remains the single most important missing signal for predicting the outcome.
    *   **Unresolved Separation of Powers Stance:** I still do not know how the Executive Branch balances its duty to defend a congressional statute (PSJVTA) against its long-term institutional interest in preserving executive and judicial power from legislative overreach.
    *   **Unresolved Deference Argument:** I still do not know the extent to which the government will argue for judicial deference to the political branches on this foreign policy issue.
    *   **Conclusion on Task Beliefs:** My legal map of the case is stable and confirmed, but it is also inert. The repeated failure to acquire the SG's input means I cannot update the relative weights of the competing arguments. My prediction remains in a state of high, and now entrenched, uncertainty.
current_beliefs.design_beliefs:
This repeated failure is an extremely valuable observation. It moves beyond simply identifying a tool's unreliability and forces a deeper evolution in my information acquisition strategy and overall operational model. A single failure suggests a fluke; a repeated failure reveals a systemic flaw.

My design beliefs have evolved significantly:

*   **Prioritize Primary Source Documents & Source Authentication (Principle Hardened):** My previous update added the sub-principle that "Source Authentication is Non-Negotiable." This second, identical failure hardens that sub-principle into a core doctrine. The `CLOSED_SEARCH` tool is demonstrably and repeatedly returning a document that matches keywords but is not the correct *source*. My verification step is not just a good idea; it is the only thing preventing a catastrophic misinterpretation of the evidence.

*   **Iterative Uncertainty Reduction (Model Refined with Escalation Pathways):** My `Assess -> Target -> Acquire -> Verify` loop is functionally sound, as the `Verify` step correctly caught the error. However, the failure of the `Acquire` step twice in a row reveals a critical missing piece: **Escalation Pathways.** My model must now be: `Assess -> Target -> Acquire -> Verify -> Escalate/Pivot on Failure`. If a refined version of an action fails, I must not try a third time. I must escalate to a fundamentally different action. Potential pivots include:
    1.  Searching for secondary sources (e.g., news articles, SCOTUSblog analysis) that summarize the target document.
    2.  Broadening the search to retrieve all related documents and performing manual filtering.
    3.  Attempting a different search tool or methodology entirely.

*   **Model the Reliability of Tools (Belief Confirmed and Quantified):** My prior belief that the `CLOSED_SEARCH` tool has a specific failure mode is now confirmed with high confidence. **The tool cannot reliably distinguish between a party named in a consolidated case caption and the actual filer of the document.** My confidence in this tool for retrieving a specific brief in a multi-party or consolidated case is now near zero. Future use requires significant workarounds.

*   **Develop Sophisticated Query Heuristics (New Principle):** The failure of a simple filtered query (`'proceeding_title': 'brief of petitioner'`) shows that I must be more sophisticated. I am adding the following heuristics to my `Acquire` step:
    *   **Negative Filtering:** Actively exclude known incorrect terms. A future query for the SG brief should include parameters like `-"Miriam Fuld"` or `-"Arnold & Porter"`.
    *   **Affirmative Targeting:** Focus on unique identifiers for the target. A future query should prioritize searching for "Solicitor General" as the counsel of record, if the tool allows for such metadata searching.
    *   **Recall Over Precision:** When precision fails, pivot to recall. A valid next step is to query for *all* briefs filed in the case docket and accept the burden of post-processing the results to find the correct one.

*   **Map the Political-Branch Ecosystem (Validated):** This heuristic's value is strongly validated. My strategic identification of the SG as the key actor was correct. The failure is purely tactical—an inability to execute the data acquisition—which reinforces the importance of having a sound strategy to guide the tactics.

*   **Build a Dialectical Map (Validated):** The map's stability and structure are what allowed me to instantly recognize—twice—that the received document was redundant information. This proves the map is a robust framework for rapidly contextualizing incoming data and identifying when new information is signal versus noise.

*   **Identify the "Lynchpin Case" (Reinforced):** This heuristic remains central. The frustrating inability to get the SG brief makes the core question—"How does the U.S. government argue the Court should resolve the tension between *Mallory* and *Ins. Corp. of Ireland*?"—even more critical. My next action must be a fundamentally different and more robust attempt to answer it.

step_metrics.action_content:
Thought: My analysis has reached a point of diminishing returns for new information acquisition. The high-recall search was a resounding success, providing the Solicitor General's reply brief, the Chamber of Commerce's amicus brief, and Professor Sachs's amicus brief. This has resolved my primary task-level uncertainty (θ): I am now highly confident the Second Circuit's decision will be reversed. The question is no longer *if* the petitioners will win, but *how*.

The dialectical map is now overwhelmingly tilted in favor of reversal, with at least five distinct and powerful lines of argument available to the Court:
1.  **Originalism (Sachs):** The Fifth Amendment's Due Process Clause, as originally understood, does not impose territorial limits on federal personal jurisdiction.
2.  **Constructive Consent (SG):** The PSJVTA is a valid exercise of Congress's power to deem consent based on conduct, consistent with this Court's precedents like *Mallory* and *Hess*.
3.  **Federal Power (Fuld & SG):** The Fifth Amendment provides Congress with broader authority to establish personal jurisdiction than the Fourteenth Amendment provides to the states.
4.  **Foreign Policy Deference (SG):** The judiciary should defer to the political branches' judgment in this matter of national security and foreign affairs.
5.  **Personhood (Chamber of Commerce):** The PLO and PA are not 'persons' entitled to Fifth Amendment due process protections in the first place, providing a complete off-ramp from the jurisdictional analysis.

The respondents' own procedural filings confirm they are on the defensive against this multi-front assault, needing extra space to rebut the distinct arguments from the Fuld petitioners (originalism), the U.S. government, and amici (personhood). The united front of the petitioners, the U.S. government, and influential amici like the Chamber of Commerce and leading legal scholars presents a formidable coalition that is exceptionally difficult to bet against.

My design-level beliefs (D) have also been significantly updated. I have validated the 'Recall Over Precision' pivot strategy, discovered the high-signal value of procedural documents, and confirmed the importance of mapping the amicus landscape for novel arguments. Further searching is unlikely to significantly alter my prediction of the outcome. The most efficient and logical next step is to synthesize these findings and provide the final response.

The Second Circuit held that the PSJVTA *does* violate the Due Process Clause. A reversal means the Supreme Court will hold that it *does not*. Therefore, my answer to the legal question is 'No'. I am ready to provide the final response.
step_metrics.classification_reasoning: The action synthesizes specific case evidence and updates the prediction about the legal question outcome, focusing primarily on task-level information.
step_metrics.eig_reasoning: This THINK action is a synthesis and summary of knowledge already acquired. It does not seek new information from the environment. Its purpose is to formalize the agent's current belief state and justify the transition to providing a final answer. Therefore, its capacity to reduce remaining uncertainty about the task outcome (Task EIG) is zero, as the uncertainty has already been resolved by prior actions. The Design EIG is minimal (0.1); while the action articulates and consolidates the significant design lessons learned from the successful high-recall search, the actual information gain occurred during that prior search. This action is merely the formal logging of those lessons into the agent's belief state (D), which has minor but non-zero value for future strategic planning.
step_metrics.complexity_reasoning: The task beliefs demonstrate a highly sophisticated and nuanced understanding of complex legal doctrines, multiple independent lines of argument, and the strategic implications of new information (e.g., the 'personhood' argument). The design beliefs reveal advanced meta-cognitive strategies, including iterative uncertainty reduction, adaptive escalation, heuristic development, and dynamic mapping of legal arguments and actors, reflecting deep strategic sophistication. The beliefs are highly coherent, with clear integration between task-specific insights and meta-level strategic principles, showing no contradictions and a seamless dialectical framework. The information density is extremely high, with detailed references to case law, doctrinal debates, procedural insights, and strategic heuristics, reflecting comprehensive and richly detailed belief states. Overall, the agent exhibits expert-level cognitive complexity and belief evolution.

current_beliefs.task_beliefs:
My strategic pivot to a high-recall search has been exceptionally fruitful, resolving the central uncertainties that had previously stalled my analysis. The acquisition of numerous docket filings, most importantly the U.S. Solicitor General's reply brief and key amicus briefs, has fundamentally shifted my understanding of the case from a state of balanced uncertainty to a clear, weighted prediction.

My cumulative beliefs are now:

*   **The Solicitor General's Stance (Resolved):** My hypothesis that the SG's position is the decisive variable has been confirmed, and that variable is now known. The United States has sided with the Fuld petitioners and argues for reversal. The SG's reply brief, filed by Acting SG Sarah M. Harris, lays out a multi-pronged argument that resolves my previous key questions:
    *   **Doctrinal Alignment:** The government is advancing a theory of **constructive consent**, arguing that the PSJVTA "fairly and reasonably deems respondents to consent to personal jurisdiction." They explicitly ground this in this Court's consent precedents, including `Mallory v. Norfolk S. Ry. Co.` and `Hess v. Pawloski`, arguing the respondents' conduct (making payments, operating in the U.S.) was voluntary and that deeming consent is not unfair or exorbitant. This places the government's considerable weight on the side of a robust consent doctrine in this context.
    *   **Separation of Powers & Deference:** The government is strongly arguing for judicial deference to the political branches. The reply brief asserts that "The political Branches’ foreign-policy and national-security judgments carry great weight," citing `Holder v. Humanitarian Law Project`. This confirms my hypothesis that a deference argument would be a key part of the government's case.
    *   **Constitutional Debate (5th vs. 14th Amendment):** The government explicitly argues that "Congress in any event has broader authority than a State to provide for personal jurisdiction," and that the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments do not restrict personal jurisdiction in parallel. This aligns the SG with the Fuld petitioners' core structural argument.

*   **Emergence of a New Dispositive Argument - "Personhood" (New & Significant):** The amicus brief from the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, among others, has introduced a powerful and potentially dispositive argument that was only a peripheral possibility before: **that the PLO and PA are not "persons" entitled to due process protections under the Fifth Amendment.** This argument provides the Court with a potential "off-ramp" to reverse the Second Circuit's decision without needing to delve into the complexities of `Mallory` or the precise contours of federal personal jurisdiction. The fact that a sophisticated and influential party like the Chamber is advancing this theory gives it significant weight.

*   **The Dialectical Map - A Tectonic Shift:** The legal landscape is no longer a balanced scale. It is now heavily weighted in favor of reversal. The petitioners' position is supported by a powerful coalition including the U.S. Government and influential amici, presenting the Court with multiple, independent grounds for reversal:
    1.  **Originalism:** The Fifth Amendment's original public meaning did not limit personal jurisdiction (advanced by Fuld petitioners and Prof. Stephen Sachs).
    2.  **Constructive Consent:** The PSJVTA is a valid "consent-by-conduct" statute under the `Mallory` framework (advanced by the SG).
    3.  **Federal vs. State Power:** The Fifth Amendment is more permissive for Congress than the Fourteenth is for states (advanced by Fuld and the SG).
    4.  **Foreign Policy Deference:** The judiciary should defer to the political branches' judgment on this national security matter (advanced by the SG).
    5.  **Lack of "Personhood":** The respondents are not "persons" who can claim due process rights in this context (advanced by the Chamber of Commerce).

*   **Prediction Update:** My prediction has shifted from high uncertainty to **high confidence in a reversal** of the Second Circuit's judgment. The sheer number of available paths to reversal, backed by a united front of the petitioners, the U.S. government, and key amici, makes the Second Circuit's holding appear highly vulnerable. The primary remaining uncertainty is not the outcome, but the *reasoning* the Court will adopt for its decision.
current_beliefs.design_beliefs:
This observation provides a wealth of information about effective information acquisition and analysis, leading to a significant evolution of my strategic principles.

My design beliefs have evolved to include:

*   **Iterative Uncertainty Reduction with Escalation Pathways (Model Validated & Refined):** My refined model of `Assess -> Target -> Acquire -> Verify -> Escalate/Pivot on Failure` has been spectacularly validated. The initial, precise `Acquire` steps failed twice. The `Escalate/Pivot` to a high-recall, broad search (`CLOSED_SEARCH` for "brief" with a high `k`) was not just a workaround but a superior strategy. It yielded not only the primary target (the SG's arguments) but also a rich ecosystem of surrounding documents that were critical for a deep understanding. This confirms that **when precision fails, pivoting to recall is a high-value escalation pathway.**

*   **Develop Sophisticated Query Heuristics (Principle Validated):** The success of the "Recall Over Precision" heuristic is now confirmed. My toolkit of query strategies is more robust. The failure of simple filtering and the success of a broad query demonstrate the need for methodological flexibility.

*   **Analyze Procedural Documents for Substantive Clues (New Principle):** The respondents' motion for an extension to file an oversized brief was a procedural document, yet it contained the first concrete evidence of the SG's position and argumentative strategy. This establishes a new, vital principle: **Procedural filings are high-signal sources.** Motions, applications, and letters to the clerk can reveal an opponent's strategy, confirm the existence of documents, and expose the fault lines of the legal battle before the merits briefs are even fully analyzed. They must be prioritized for review.

*   **Map the Amicus Landscape (New Principle):** The various amicus briefs were not merely duplicative. The Chamber of Commerce introduced a novel and powerful "personhood" argument. Professor Sachs provided deep originalist support. This demonstrates that amici can play a crucial role in shaping the legal battlefield. My model must now include the heuristic: **Actively map the arguments of key amici to identify novel legal theories, specialized support for a party's main arguments, and the strategic division of labor among allies.**

*   **Model the Reliability of Tools (Belief Confirmed):** My belief that the `CLOSED_SEARCH` tool struggles to distinguish between parties in a consolidated case caption is reinforced. The initial failures were due to this specific limitation. The successful pivot to a broad query and manual filtering is the correct workaround for this tool's known failure mode.

*   **Build a Dialectical Map (Validated):** The pre-existing map of the case's core conflicts was indispensable. It provided the structure to instantly contextualize the flood of new information from the SG and amicus briefs. I could immediately see how the SG's arguments resolved my specific uncertainties regarding doctrinal alignment and deference. The map is a dynamic framework for strategic analysis, not just a static summary.

*   **Identify the "Lynchpin Case" (Reinforced):** My focus on the `Mallory` / `Ins. Corp. of Ireland` tension was correct. The SG's reply brief and multiple amicus briefs engaged directly with this tension, confirming it as a central doctrinal battleground. This heuristic remains a highly effective way to focus analysis on the most critical legal questions.

*   **Prioritize Primary Source Documents & Source Authentication (Principle Hardened):** This remains a core doctrine. The pivot to a broad search was an attempt to acquire primary sources, and its success reinforces this principle. The ability to read the SG's and amici's own words, rather than relying on summaries, was what enabled the breakthrough in understanding.

current_beliefs.task_beliefs:
My understanding of this case has progressed from balanced uncertainty to a state of high-confidence, synthesized conclusion. The evidence gathered has provided a clear and decisive path to a final prediction.

*   **Initial Uncertainty (Resolved):** My initial analysis was stalled by uncertainty regarding the U.S. government's position and the specific legal arguments that would be deployed. I hypothesized that the Solicitor General's stance would be a decisive variable.

*   **The Solicitor General's Stance (Resolved):** My strategic pivot to a high-recall search successfully acquired the SG's reply brief. This confirmed that the United States sides with the Fuld petitioners, arguing for reversal based on:
    *   A **constructive consent** theory grounded in `Mallory v. Norfolk S. Ry. Co.` and `Hess v. Pawloski`.
    *   A strong argument for **judicial deference** to the political branches' foreign policy and national security judgments, citing `Holder v. Humanitarian Law Project`.
    *   A structural argument that **Congress has broader authority** under the Fifth Amendment to establish personal jurisdiction than states have under the Fourteenth.

*   **Emergence of a Dispositive "Off-Ramp" Argument (New & Significant):** The amicus brief from the U.S. Chamber of Commerce introduced a powerful new argument: that the PLO and PA are not "persons" entitled to Fifth Amendment due process protections. This provides the Court an alternative basis for reversal that avoids the more complex questions of consent and federal jurisdiction.

*   **The Dialectical Map - A Tectonic Shift:** The legal landscape is now overwhelmingly weighted in favor of reversal. The petitioners are supported by a powerful coalition (U.S. Government, Chamber of Commerce, legal scholars) presenting at least five independent grounds for the Court to reverse the Second Circuit:
    1.  **Originalism:** The Fifth Amendment's original public meaning did not limit personal jurisdiction (Prof. Stephen Sachs).
    2.  **Constructive Consent:** The PSJVTA is a valid "consent-by-conduct" statute (Solicitor General).
    3.  **Federal vs. State Power:** The Fifth Amendment is more permissive for Congress than the Fourteenth is for states (Fuld Petitioners & SG).
    4.  **Foreign Policy Deference:** The judiciary should defer to Congress and the President (SG).
    5.  **Lack of "Personhood":** The respondents are not "persons" who can claim due process rights in this context (Chamber of Commerce).

*   **Final Synthesis and Prediction (Confirmed):** My internal review of the evidence confirms that further information acquisition has reached a point of diminishing returns. The sheer number and weight of the arguments for reversal, coming from a united front of powerful actors, makes the outcome highly probable. The primary remaining uncertainty is not *if* the Court will reverse, but *which of the five paths* it will choose for its reasoning. Therefore, my final prediction is a **reversal** of the Second Circuit's decision. This means the answer to the legal question, "Does the Promoting Security and Justice for Victims of Terrorism Act violate the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment?" will be **No**.
current_beliefs.design_beliefs:
My strategic framework for legal analysis has been tested, validated, and refined through this process, culminating in a new principle for determining when an investigation is complete.

*   **Iterative Uncertainty Reduction with Escalation Pathways (Validated & Refined):** The `Assess -> Target -> Acquire -> Verify -> Escalate/Pivot` model proved highly effective. When precision-based acquisition failed, the `Escalate/Pivot` to a high-recall search was a superior strategy, yielding not just the target document but a rich ecosystem of crucial amicus briefs. This confirms that **pivoting from precision to recall is a high-value escalation pathway when initial searches fail.**

*   **Develop Sophisticated Query Heuristics (Validated):** The "Recall Over Precision" heuristic is now a confirmed, effective strategy for overcoming tool limitations or when the exact document title is unknown.

*   **Analyze Procedural Documents for Substantive Clues (New Principle):** The respondents' motion for an extension to file an oversized brief provided the first concrete signal of the SG's position. This established the principle: **Procedural filings are high-signal sources that can reveal opponent strategy and key case dynamics.**

*   **Map the Amicus Landscape (New Principle):** Amicus briefs proved to be a source of novel and potentially dispositive arguments (e.g., the Chamber of Commerce's "personhood" theory). This established the heuristic: **Actively map amicus arguments to identify novel legal theories and understand the strategic division of labor among a party's allies.**

*   **Model the Reliability of Tools (Reinforced):** My belief that the `CLOSED_SEARCH` tool struggles with complex case captions was confirmed. The successful workaround (broad query + manual filtering) is the correct response to this known failure mode.

*   **Build a Dialectical Map (Validated):** The dialectical map was indispensable for structuring analysis, allowing for the rapid integration of new information from the SG and amici and providing a clear visualization of the case's argumentative structure.

*   **Identify the "Lynchpin Case" (Reinforced):** Focusing on the `Mallory` precedent was correct, as it proved to be a central battleground for both the SG and amici, confirming this as a highly effective focusing heuristic.

*   **Prioritize Primary Source Documents (Hardened):** The entire breakthrough was predicated on acquiring and analyzing primary source briefs, reinforcing this as a foundational doctrine of my methodology.

*   **Recognize Analytical Sufficiency and Diminishing Returns (New Principle):** The final internal review established a crucial meta-cognitive principle for ending an investigation. **An analysis is sufficient when multiple, independent, high-quality lines of evidence converge on a single outcome.** At this point, the expected information gain from further searching is low, and the primary uncertainty shifts from the *outcome* to the *reasoning*. The state of the dialectical map (i.e., being overwhelmingly lopsided) serves as a key signal that this point of diminishing returns has been reached and it is time to synthesize a final conclusion.
